title: How can we improve sanitation and better manage human waste in low-income urban communities?

bundling_sanitizing_products_with_toilet.description: Purchasing hygiene / sanitation products provides free access to the best latrines.
bundling_sanitizing_products_with_toilet.creator: 9af153334a613b3bc769efffa8fa73f3

comments.text: http://www.pellet-plants.com/newsI am very pleased to leave my comment here. This article is quite interesting.
http://www.pellet-plants.com/product/index-4-2.htmlIt is a chance for me to give my voice here and I want to know more.
I like the bundling concept as it creates incentives for both consumers and MNCs.

Just wanted to say how much I liked this concept, Dominique, as well as your other concept about community loans for toilets. I think in both examples you've identified great strategies (in this case, bundling; in the other case, community pressures and relationships) to incent people to behave in certain ways. Nice job!
Maybe this can be done the other way round too. Residents can get coupons on every use of public toilet, which they can collect & later redeem to get hygiene/sanitation products for free.

Wow, this is a great creative idea Dominique! More low-cost toilets for all, improving hygiene habits awareness and motivation through smart bundling, marketing/trial/recurring sales-generating benefits to the sponsoring company. Awesome!

I like the idea of bundling hygiene/sanitation product purchases at the latrine site with access to a better toilet. It would certainly help to raise awareness and might allow users to try new hygiene/sanitation products which they might not otherwise. It would be interesting to think about what the price point for the products would have to be in order to make this desirable and fair.

peepoo_version_2.description: The PeePoo is a brilliant project that addresses existing “flying toilet” behaviors through a single-use sanitizing toilet bag that improves hygiene and creates fertilizer. As the project has been field testing (well worth a look: http://www.peepoople.com/pdf/GTZ_toilet%20bag.pdf , http://www.peepoople.com/pdf/Peepoo.Impact.Assessment.Report.pdf ), there’s likely to be iterative improvements over time. This concept envisions an “upgrade” to the PeePoo that 1) PeePoo users could trade-up to or start off with directly if funds allow, and 2) Bucket Latrine/Chamber Pot/Public Toilet users could switch to for a similar cost. It very much builds upon Jeff’s “PeePoo Bag” inspiration (http://bit.ly/ccACaG), Adriana’s “Toilet Lid” inspiration (http://bit.ly/c6kNIo), and Jocelyn’s connecting comment.
peepoo_version_2.creator: b15ab3f829f0f897fe507ef548741afb

comments.text: HI, to build on this further, have you considered adding some kind of twist between usages. To reduce odor between uses, if you secured the bottom of the bag to the bottom of the bucket and then twisted the top, maybe you could twist off the previous deposit - and end up with a kind of string of sausages - not sure if this would help or not - just a random thought.

I must say that's a creative and interesting idea Sarah! At the same time, I never thought that human excrement and sausages would become associated in my mind, although now that I think of it, there is a connection =P
The Dabbawalla distribution system could be emulated here!:http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zKmp1sZPMUk

Vincent, your idea is that the bags are collected by a service provider? If so, I imagine the bags could be simpler than Peepoo, which reduces the cost. Peepoo bags are made to be dropped anywhere, since they possess an inner layer of urea, etc.. For the use of manure in a biodigester, for example, would suffice that the bags were biodegradable ... or not? What do you think?

Has Wilhelmson, the original inventor of the Pee-Poo bags, been contacted regarding their recent interest on OpenIDEO?  There are a lot of good opportunities here so It would be very cool to hear what he thought of some of the other users' suggestions.

If separation of urine and feces is found to be important (perhaps for lower utilization of Peepoo bags, improved conversion efficiency into fertilizer/energy, etc.), the "Hybrid Chamber Pot and Watering Can" ( http://bit.ly/hIBcvt ) may make a good complimentary product. And of course, a lot of these shortlisted concepts would work well together in an integrated system. For example, this concept would go well with Navigation System for Flying Toilets, Get Paid For Your Poop, etc.
Great! :) It should be called a 'PooBelle' ;) I like this idea a lot as it is very simple and gives a lot of freedom. I think it would be complete, combined with the "Get paid for your poop" idea!

I really like that Vincent has mashed together various ideas here.
Actually Demian  you wouldn't be the only one to nit-pick on the Pee-Poo bags. Sanitation + development blogs have been rife with commentary since it's launch. Here's one that lists some pros *and* cons  http://bit.ly/eiOPSy

Astoundingly great concept Vincent!The Pee Poo bag is brilliant.The more research I do the more alarmed I am at how many people live without toilets.  Actually I just read somewhere that more people in India have access to mobile phones than have access to a toilet.  Shameful that we have come so far and yet left so many people behind.The Pee Poo bag is a cheap, super simple solution to a huge global problem.I like it a lot.  Wilhelmson should be highly commended for inventing it.  If I were hyper-critical from a design/usability standpoint I would say that there might be a slight issue with the inner bag being larger/wider than the outer bag.  Looks like the use could be a little awkward.  Especially filled with its 'precious cargo'.  But I wouldn't dare to nit-pick such a gem.  Overall the Pee Poo bag is an elegantly simple solution to a chronic problem that remains unsolved for well over o BILLION people in this world.  Terrible.  I shudder to think how much I take my toilet for granted.Thanks again for the concept!

If the bags are left out in the sun, how hot will they get? The humanure guidebook says that if excrement can be heated to 55-60C for several hours then all germs will be killed. In hotter, sunnier countries, is this an option. What if the bags where better absorbers, had a rough finish and black? In what conditoins could they reach this crucial temperature.
biodegradable dog poop bags cost less than 0.05 each. Is it feasible to give them away for free? Bags are easily carriable in a pocket so everyone can have them. Is there now any excuse for not using one?
If bags can be easil and cleanly sealed they, with their content can be easily sealed. This also has the huge benifit that urine is seperated from excrement! In additon, the urine is left where it is, it will be a good feralizer and it does, I believe, carry germs. Is this true????

Very true and thanks for the link Svava. By combining such generally temporarily used portable/emergency toilets with the biodegradable, fertilizer-producing PeePoo bags, the PeePoo version 2 would hopefully provide a more hygienic and environmental longer-term solution.
This reminds me of the American Redcross emergency bucket with seathttp://www.sdarc.org/store/products2/tabid/321/productid/108/sename/emergency-toilet-bucket-wseat/default.aspx

community_sanitation_engineers_for_kumas.description: Community Sanitation Engineers for Kumasi-To truly transform the sanitation situation in Kumasi will require the education of a new class of professionals to do the actual work of sanitation, and the work of educating hundreds of thousands of people on how and why to participate in keeping their neighborhood and city clean and free from waste borne disease.
community_sanitation_engineers_for_kumas.creator: 299453c107788839f427a6169f591ac4

comments.text: I posted an inspiration on Sulabh in this challenge, but I was not aware they have training opportunities for foreign students. Thanks for the contribution Alessandro!

Good idea, Sabra. Sulabh International also has an academy for training specialists in sanitation, with places for foreign students. They could form a team of teachers who could be the multipliers of that knowledge in Ghana. Could be distributed scholarships to a group of university students in Ghana to do this specialization. See link: http://bit.ly/ggsMXc

Avi, great link! Thanks! It's good to know there are such well tested working models to draw on. The video really has a lot of good detail on stuff like language independent technical training. So inspiring to see women from different continents learning together...

Good concept! This is similar to the women solar engineers being trained and deployed to electrify villages by the Barefoot College in Rajasthan:http://www.ndtv.com/video/player/the-unstoppable-indians/the-barefoot-college-in-tilonia-ajmer/138390

toilet_infrastructure_job_social_space_m.description: In South African townships I noticed that many residents take an informal ownership over the public toilet located near their house. In some cases this means charging people in the street, or visitors to the area to use the toilet. The 'owner' usually has a key to the toilet to ensure it is not vandalised. I also noticed the social spaces created around the toilet/laundry areas. Amplifying these ideas, infrastructure could become a business whereby a local trader sells goods such as toilet paper & hot water (solar powered?) in return for services - maintenance of the infrastructure.This would create an economy around the service point that would also provide jobs for residents, and ensure the maintenance of the facility which is a core problem.
toilet_infrastructure_job_social_space_m.creator: fe96e1403409d1d80835741b2edc6e70

comments.text: For sure, definite ability to increase the scope and services of these nodes/service points as you suggested. Perhaps based on the site (space, participation level of residents, budget & infrastructure available) the complexity of the infrastructure could increase or decrease (eg. treatment plant, electricity etc etc are added on accordingly, or even over time as budget and resident interest and involvement increases)

I love your concept! I think that the idea of organizing life around the 'water' and 'energy' is great. Maybe it should also be equipped with a small treatment plant, or it should also generally be a place where you can get electricity - using solars, as you wrote, or small wind rotors that are such a hot topic right now  - as electricity is also an issue in rural areas in Ghana?

toilet_infrastructure_job_social_space_m.title: toilet = infrastructure + job + social space = maintenance + ownership

refrigeration_is_hot.description: Sanitation isn't sexy, unfortunately. But refrigeration? That seems to be a big thing here in Kumasi.
refrigeration_is_hot.creator: dde2fb7aaee01b358a14703a9551c154

comments.text:
Remember, the leftovers from biogas production are clean, pathogen free composted fertilizer and some water. You are using the process of cleaning up the waste through bacterial action to produce clean burning fuel. Sanitation is accomplished by giving human and animal waste its proper place in the economy. The solution to most of the problems of poverty and pollution on this planet could be gained by simply cleaning up all human and much livestock waste in this way. When you add the energy potential of neighborhood scale fuel alcohol production from agriculture and food waste (NOT MADE FROM FOOD), you see how easy it could be to truly live well within our carbon budget. 
Alcohol production also has byproducts of compost and water, with the addition of livestock feed (fermented fodder beets are  highly regarded as feed for dairy cows), and even human food (Spent brewers grains make really good nutritious bread) Alcohol can be made from kelp farmed on polluted water to clean it up, or from food waste, or any number of non food plants with available sugars.When all leftover solids and liquids are returned to the soil after alcohol production, so is most of the carbon.http://www.permaculture.com/ has information about the history and current state of fuel alcohol industry.

When a toilet fuels the refrigerator, directly by household level biogas production, or indirectly through a centralized neighborhood gas to electricity plant, the toilet enables the aspiration of operating a refrigerator. I wonder if it would be possible to make that connection more direct for the user with incentives based on biogas program participation to reduce the price of a refrigerator and/or other tech that people want.
It would be even better if the refrigerators were adsorption units powered by solar thermal. Turning heat directly into cold is such elegant tech! That would free up the energy produced as biogas for other uses such as lighting, fans, air compressors for power tools, and electricity for sewing machines.

refrigeration_is_hot.title: Refrigeration is Hot

improved_bucket_latrine.description: An improved bucket latrine that tries to solve the issues of past bucket latrines.  From the research, it seems that bucket latrines had high adoption in Kumasi but failed because of service/collection issues.  It is also very much in line with the 'pee-poo version 2'  concept from Vincent.
improved_bucket_latrine.creator: d814e015f931aba24d24c2f12025dc3c

comments.text: Great thoughts around services, behavioral nudges, financing, and value adds Jeff. I think I missed seeing this concept earlier.
I specially like your notion of staggered pricing for value additions.

making_sanitation_fun.description:
Domestos along with digital agency Lean Mean Fighting Machine have worked together to make flush tracker http://www.flushtracker.com/ in aid of world toilet day.
Flush Tracker allows you to enter the time and location of your most recent toilet visit, and uses Google Maps to let you track your faeces as they make their way through your local sewers

Read more: http://www.metro.co.uk/tech/847768-flush-tracker-lets-you-track-your-poo#ixzz17hSfwIzX

The Flush tracker raises awareness of sanitation but at the same time does it in a light hearted way. The response was truly amazing with the servers crashing on day one!
making_sanitation_fun.creator: 80fa1bf5dc7b7b6f55e54661b4ca5a0d

comments.text: Too cool! http://www.flushtracker.com/ is the link. I wish there was one for where I live. I bet this concept could be used to generate ad revenue from related businesses to fund sanitation projects.

making_sanitation_fun.title: Making sanitation fun

composting_collection.description: The horse poop in Vienna never hits the ground...gathered and I imagine used to help grow the green spaces of the city. Are there ways to be more direct about designing to support natural cycles, even in urban settings?

comments.text: Actually, this makes me wonder: where does all the horse manure go in these cases? There are so many cities around the world that take tourists around on horses (ie: Central Park in NYC). Where does all the manure go?

This simple collection sock could be used to collect animal manure wherever people use animal powered transport. If the manure had a cash value by weight at the local biogas/compost facility, people would be motivated to make/buy the manure collection containers and transport manure to the facility for processing.

We need to use incredible marketing to sell sanitation.
make_me_feel_good_about_owning_a_toilet.creator: ad3ad14deeacd26502d0036312c4efa8

comments.text:
Hi Andy, I am TED addicted :D Totally agree. These are the three steps to be followed in all kinds of projects: 1-  Take real time data and feed it back immediately into the product (or service)2-  Use Local Entrepreneur talent 3-  Making Social Marketing appealing

get_paid_for_your_poop.description: This concept is directly inspired by Alessandro’s call to “imagine that people would not have to pay anything to use the bathroom, but that these bathrooms were small factories that produce gas and fertilizer”, as well as by the many other OpenIDEO contributions that I’ve linked to in the text and to the right. I will focus on trying to propose a framework that pays for poop and makes sustainable sense for the challenge’s focus area of Kumasi, Ghana.
get_paid_for_your_poop.creator: b15ab3f829f0f897fe507ef548741afb

comments.text: I was reading the OpenIDEO case and it talks about this challenge. I was wondering what the winning concepts would be.It really surprised me! Thank you for that.
I love that you are working on two problems at once- the problem of sanitation and the problem of energy. Combine and conquer!

Thanks Vincent!  I think you are onto something in that there is an economic model in there somewhere that, if the correct infrastructure and behavior patterns are established, can work and change the entire system.  The trick is just fitting all the various pieces together correctly.  But it can be done!  Thanks again!

Also, Demian's concept "Preventative Medicine: Reward Sanitary Practices" (http://bit.ly/grwOVF) does a great job of layout out how avoiding sanitation-related disease outbreaks produces savings that may justify some of the costs of paying for poop. There are also some insightful building comments here.

http://www.sintex-plastics.com/ has a line of biogas plants sized from .5 to 5 cubic meters. These household sized biogas plants are made of plastic, tough, but extremely light. The three different sizes are to accommodate the manure of one, two or four livestock animals along with the human waste.This method makes much more biogas than human waste alone.
Biogas can be generated in what amounts to a large plastic bag. I know people who have done it in a water bed liner, though this method is not very efficient or sustainable. Biogas can be burned as its made to generate electricity or mechanical energy. (This eliminates storage dangers for pressurized gases), or it can be delivered in a similar way to propane or other forms of natural gas.
Thanks Sabra. Conceptually, it looks like this could be possible. Interested to see whether we can find a way to bring this to life as we delve more into the details.
Wow, Vincent. Great drawing together. I think this presentation gives this set of ideas the clarity they needed. Thanks for your effort and example.

get_paid_for_your_poop.title: Get Paid For Your Poop

another_example_of_composting_toilets_le.description: A group I worked with in the spring, All Hands Disaster Response (formerly Hands On Disaster Response) built composting toilets to provide for the local volunteers that joined them for lunch and English classes at the base site.  As word spread, they decided to build more throughout the community.  You could contact Steph, Jess or Mark with All Hands (hands.org) to find out what the latest news is on the project, and how they enacted it, but this seems an elegant solution for a place without clean water, with limited building supplies and a dire need for sanitation efforts even before the January 2010 earthquake that disrupted thousands of homes.

making_private_toilets_public.description: This concept is inspired by the following article “Toilets are being converted to bedrooms in Kumasi “ (http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/artikel.php?ID=165948), as its direct commentary on the toilet situation in Kumasi (the region this challenge is focused on) from Ghana’s most widely read newspaper (the Daily Graphic). This article highlights the trend of people “converting…bathrooms in their houses into bedrooms for renting”, which actually violates the Kumasi Metropolitan Assembly’s by-laws that “every household in the metropolis is expected to have a toilet facility”, though unsurprising given the city’s ~16% unemployment rate. However, this article also contains the hints towards a possible solution: income generation.
making_private_toilets_public.creator: b15ab3f829f0f897fe507ef548741afb

comments.text: As an alternative to "business in a box" set-up model, you could perhaps reduce initial upfront costs by doing a lease-to-own or rental model for the setup pieces of the toilet for new home toilet businesses. Great idea.
I like how you link providing public/private toilets with better housing Demian. I wonder what other ways having a toilet could be used to leverage improvements in quality of life?

Maybe residential houses could be designed so that the bathroom had an entrance from the interior of the house, as is typical, and also an entrance from the exterior of the house that could be used by neighbors paying to use the toilet.  Local governments might even be persuaded to offer tax breaks for houses with bathrooms built to be used by the public as this would help to alleviate demand on public facilities.Good idea Vincent!

This is a really interesting concept - I love the idea of household toilets being a potential source of revenue for families. Seems like this would provide a financial incentive for a landlord or a family living in a compound to invest in a toilet and then charge their neighbors for using it.

@Sabra: yes, let's make the most of existing resources. And nice connecting of the dots between "Making Private Toilets Public" and "Get Paid For Your Poop"!
@Meena: thanks for the helpful information on public pay toilets in India. I think the OpenIDEO Ghana field team also compiled costs of various sanitation options at http://ghanasan.wordpress.com/2010/12/05/the-cost-of-doing-business/

The more I think about this idea, the better I like it. People can use what already exists in a more efficient way that leads to increased income for households that already have a toilet. If disposing of the poop actually became a source of income too, they could even have money to build an extra "room" to rent out.
I know that in Mumbai many slum residents pay Rs 1 to use public toilets everyday. The Potty Project also reported on toilets run on micro-payments across slums in India.

Hi Alessandro, thanks for your very valid point about affordability. I agree that ways must be found to lower usage cost to the end user, whether through lowering the actual toilet setup/operation/maintenance costs, supplementary revenue generation (that could also have wider economic and environmental benefits), or other creative methods. This concept is hopefully a way to increase access, whether using the existing infrastructure or an improved infrastructure like you envision. At the very least, increasing the # of public/semi-public toilets will increase competition, hopefully leading to better toilet quality and lower prices. Regardless, it should be financially viable, considering that ~38% of Kumasi residents currently use pay public toilets though, if they could afford it, they may prefer the quality of the private household toilets that ~51% of residents use (stats from Kumasi Metropolitan Authority). Of course, we must also find solutions for the remaining  ~11% of the population that resort to other generally free means (flying toilets, open defecation, etc.). I will try to think more about this in future concepting.

In a city where people earn so little money and there is an unemployment rate so high is that this kind of business would be viable? People would pay to use it? The money people are willing to pay would be interesting because of the dirty work that the owners of the toilets would have to accomplish? Now... imagine that people would not have to pay anything to use the bathroom, but that these bathrooms were small factories that produce gas and fertilizer ... this could generate an income interest for these micro entrepreneurs ... gas, for example, could be sold to a neighbor ... is just an idea, ok? ... congratulations for your work!

urinal_targets.description: According to Urinalfly.com, etching or adhering the image of a fly to a urinal reduces spillage by 85%, encouraging toilet users to better their aim.
urinal_targets.creator: 018271c769550f277be5e7230b4eafc8

comments.text:
I've read about these urinals in the book "Nudge", by Richard Thaler & Cass Sunstein. If i'm not mistaken, the point of the fly was that "if the user has something to asim at, their precision will improve". In other words, it doesn't have to be a fly picture in the urinal, any sort of "target" should suffice, opening up a new and interesting avenue for experimentation.
I'm sure that this particular inspiration will be of just as much value for people in the developing as well as in the developed world alike!
On a follow up note - this concept was translated to targets hung in conventional toilet bowls for toddler (and other) training and successfully commercialised here in Australia.
Fab inspiration Lindsey! Agreed Pedro  we instantly thought of Nudge too.

urinal_targets.title: Urinal targets

what_to_do_with_doggie_doo.description: Dog poop is disposed of in various ways including simply being left on the ground (in volume, can spread disease, contaminate water supply, and emit greenhouse gas), bag & trash (plastic bag & contents don't decompose and take space in landfill), flushed down the toilet (to be processed along with human waste), composted (already mentioned in other inspirations), and bacteria/enzyme digested (covered more below).
what_to_do_with_doggie_doo.creator: b15ab3f829f0f897fe507ef548741afb

comments.text:
Is there any information on the cost of these machines and the bags and how much energy they produce?
it seems more like a simbolic gesture than a solution.
The bags, however, that's different and brilliant. How much are they? can they be made locally and cheaper? Can people pick up their own poop like they do with dogs? If the bags are free I can't see why not.

Hi Vincent,
Thank you for the out-of-box inspiration. Hope I will be able to build on it.

Hi Vincent,It's actually really smart to think about dog poop as inspiration for the human waste question. In my experience, many dog owners take the issue of dog poop clean up very seriously - in some dog friendly communities, there's actually social pressure and a stigma attached to being caught not picking up poop! It makes me wonder how we could capture that same sense of vigilance that dog owners have about dog poop and apply it to human waste disposal? How can communities create social rules/contracts around disposing of human poop properly? Very interesting questions....

"For WMI, a company in existence for only nine years, the deal was audacious in  the extreme; it required the assembly of 2,500 workers, many of them recruited in India, and all of whom needed housing, medical services, and extensive training to meet the Saudis's fastidious standards. As Huizenga told Fortune, April 7, 1980, "We had to succeed. We couldn't afford to fail." Succeed WMI did, becoming in effect the world's first international supplier of sanitation services, and paving the way for a plethora of subsequent contracts.
Soon the city of Buenos Aires turned to WMI for help with its waste program, in 1980 giving the firm a contract for the disposal of garbage generated by two million residents and a substantial portion of the city's commercial and industrial concerns. In rapid succession followed agreements with Jeddah, Saudi Arabia; Caracas, Venezuela; Brisbane, Australia; and, in the late 1980s, a number of European cities as well as Hong Kong. Great points everyone. I found some really great resources on the Web (http://tilz.tearfund.org/Publications/Footsteps+1-10/Footsteps+9/Building+a+pit+latrine.htm and http://www.lnt.org/programs/principles_3.php) that seem to address some of the issues raised.

However, there are many good designs out there for other styles of latrine without this vulnerability using  locally available building materials. Avi has some really good links below.

adopt_a_drain.description: Shifting drain cleanliness responsibility from the city to the residents
adopt_a_drain.creator: 4f8b3ea88d13faf1a2fe3d5dc729c8e3

comments.text: The Orangi Pilot Project in Karachi, Pakistan has been effective in getting users to take responsibility for building local sewerage systems where none exist - often when informal settlements develop there is no connection from the house to the main sewer. http://www.oppinstitutions.org/Low%20cost%20sanitation%20program%20in%20orangi.htmSo I definitely think it's possible, nice work.

Interesting concept Svava!  I wonder, though, if having outside groups and organizations 'adopt' sections of drain, much like the 'Adopt a Highway' program in the U.S. , and then pay workers with those funds to go around and clean them would be another way to approach this?  A concern for me is that giving the incremental responsibility to residents might raise a lot of questions and lead to neighborly tension.  For example, do people with longer stretches of drain in front of their house get paid more and, if so, who decides that?  Do people upstream have an advantage over people downstream in that they could just push the waste in their drain towards their downstream neighbor?  Would people complain that their neighbors are not cleaning their portion of the drain as well as they are but are still getting paid the same amount?  Etc., etc.  Putting the 'adoptive' responsibility in the hands of outside organizations might help to circumvent these issues.But you are correct, cleaner drains can be very helpful in contributing to a general improved sanitation situation and it is an opportunity worth exploring.Thanks again for the concept!

Interesting way to localize the responsibility and accountability to those who are directly exposed to the issue. Could imagine people being reminded by their neighbor to avoid throwing certain items in the drain.
Could a buyer be found for the plastic bottles? Those are the plastics that acrylic fleece and plastic lumber are made from. It's really bad when too many of them get crushed into the soil, too.

preventative_medicine_reward_sanitary_pr.description: Open defecation and human waste disposal is gravely unsanitary. It's practice can contaminate drinking water and soil and cause disease and illness to quickly spread throughout a community.  What if people in poor communities were paid to practice proper sanitation?
preventative_medicine_reward_sanitary_pr.creator: 7c8e822d3f154bb2b046f6e1085eea54

comments.text: http://www.pellet-plants.com/product/index.htmlYour article is amazing and it will surely catch more peoples focus.
It is a chance for me to give my voice here and I want to know more.http://www.pellet-plants.com

Sabra, thanks for the comment!  Great thought!  Yes, all sorts of non-cash rewards could also work as incentive.  School supplies, food staples, cooking oil, shoes, etc., etc.  You are right that care has to be taken so as the system and the people using are not exploited in some way.  But if handled correctly rewards can work to change behavior.  And public health spending in the long run.Thanks again!

Very good thought Demian. I like your point that paying people a small amount for practicing disease reduction strategies like human waste sanitation actually saves a lot of money (and suffering) in the long run. One thought, brought up in the WOSUK presentation, is that rewards for appropriate sanitation behavior can include things other than money. School supplies, uniforms and scholarships for children to attend school encourage aspirational behavior in a way that simple cash payments don't.These non-cash benefits are much less likely to be appropriated by others as well.The distribution of these rewards can also be structured in ways that discourage envy (by including the family and community in benefiting from each person's appropriate sanitation) and reduce the possibility of theft and resale (e.g.:storing school supplies at school except the ones in immediate use) In an area so full of poverty, it's important to reward people in ways that don't end up with them being victimized by criminals or abusive family members.

Thanks for the comment Alessandro!  Yes, it is a similar concept to Vincent's "Get Paid For Your Poop".  But it differs in that Vincent is proposing a payment structure based on the use of human waste as a resource to be processed and utilized.  My concept is is a proposal to overturn the current pay-per-use equation, incentivizing people to use the public toilets which would then keep feces from contaminating open areas and water sources.  The main purpose of this being to maintain good public health.  Less feces contaminating the environment would prevent the outbreak and spread disease.  The less disease in need of treatment, the less government and international health aid workers and supplies are needed.  Thereby saving a lot of money in the long run.  So much of our spending for healthcare is reactionary and treatment based.  It might be much more cost effective, and much cheaper, to look at public health from a prevention perspective.  Paying people a small amount to practice good sanitation could be a good place to start.Thanks again for your comment!

Good idea, Demian. It's similar to the concept "Get Paid For Your Poop" by Vincent.I think the government should always think "what can we do to spend less?" If the government can spend less on health and sanitation, because people are less sick and because they are profiting from the sale of fertilizers, good. Maybe get at the point that people need not spend anything to get rid of their manure. If we get to equilibrium between revenue and expenditure, would be perfect. However, I think it would be very difficult to get someone to pay for their waste. Maybe to install themselves micro-factories, controlled by small local entrepreneurs, but not in government projects.

preventative_medicine_reward_sanitary_pr.title: Preventative Medicine: Reward Sanitary Practices!

comments.text: Vinegar is a really good nontoxic cleaner. People can easily make it at home or as a small business from a variety of food scraps or agricultural waste. Anything with a bit of sugar will work to make vinegar. Vinegar is acidic enough to clean up poop splatters safely. The smell is strong at first but dissipates quickly, removing the poop odor as it goes. Diluted vinegar (3/1) also is a great skin cleaner and hair rinse, and the method of choice for cleaning skin areas affected by fungal infections.
We'd love to see more ideas for cleaning products that could be used as part of a household sanitation system. Other possibilities that could build on this?

poop_to_fuel_pellets.description: As the elderly population in Japan increases, companies there have developed technology that turns adult diapers (and child diapers) into sterile, odorless, concentrated, portable pellets that can be used for fuel and construction (http://news.cnet.com/8301-17938_105-20004020-1.html, http://www.japantoday.com/category/lifestyle/view/used-adult-diapers-get-new-life-as-fuel).
poop_to_fuel_pellets.creator: b15ab3f829f0f897fe507ef548741afb

comments.text: woodpellet machine  Your article is meaningful and it helps me a lot.It is a chance for me to give my voice here and I like this very much.

Vincent, there is some sort of equipment that turns human faeces into pellets to burn? The feces of herbivorous animals contains a large amount of cellulose, due to food and are really used in stoves. But there is something related to the use of human feces? If there would be great, since the wood-burning stoves (and pellets, animal feces, etc. ...) are still the most used worldwide.

The waste water from paper making could potentially be treated by using it as a biofuel feedstock. Lignins removed from the paper pulp and dried can be burned directly or used wet to generate biogas or other biofuels. After the water is treated/removed from the biofuel, it can be used to irrigate paper crops.

This is a really good idea, but I have a lot of questions. I am very curious about what the paper for the diapers etc, would be made from, and where it would be made. Could paper with the right qualities be made locally, maybe by recycling paper or banana leaves? What's the resource efficiency of producing it like? How much water is required to make the paper? What is the cost of treating that water? If the water is transported in, how much does that cost? If paper is sourced non-locally, how much does transport cost? How clean do the pellets burn with different fuel/air mixtures or types of stoves? How expensive are the stoves or furnaces necessary to burn the pellets?  How much carbon dioxide and other pollutants are released into the atmosphere with this method compared with simple composting or biogas?(think carbon credits and treating in place here) What's the best poop to paper ratio? (this informs cost analysis)How maintainable is the technology? Can local people fix it or be trained to fix it when it breaks? Who makes the machine to make the pellets? How hard are parts to get or make ? Is a maintenance contract with the tech provider required to keep the system running over the coming decades? How much does that cost? How will the service and supply chain be kept intact through the life cycle of the plant? How will replacement costs be financed ? This could easily become an expensive relic if the paper supply chain becomes problematic due to rising transportation fuel prices or drought, depending where the fiber for the paper is sourced, and at what scale the solution is applied. I still really like the idea, but please be careful in how it's applied.

I love this idea.  If the technology is there, the infrastructure can be established and any cultural stigma be gotten over, waste-to-fuel-pellets could help to solve two major problems at once: sanitation and deforestation.  Let's figure this out to make it happen!  Thanks for the concept Vincent!

i wrote this in my evaluation:
The pellet-making-process could very likely be made highly efficient and income-generating by-products could be heat (for generating electricity) gas (for cooking or to generate electricity) fertilizers (for farmers)
So you could pay the customers that "sell" their poop to this scheme!

group_buying_toilets.description: In the same way that microfinance has leveraged group lending to ensure accountability and repayment, NGOs or even for-profit organizations can engage communities in "group buys" of toilets.  Communities would pool together resources to apply for a 'toilet loan' and collectively repay that loan.  If the group defaulted or didn't maintain the toilet correctly, everyone would lose free access to the toilet (the NGO or company could take over and turn the toilet into a regular public latrine).
group_buying_toilets.creator: 9af153334a613b3bc769efffa8fa73f3

comments.text: I posted this on another post also, but orangi pilot project may have some useful implementation lessons for you to build on http://www.oppinstitutions.org/Low%20cost%20sanitation%20program%20in%20orangi.htm

Thanks Dominique! I like this concept.  Not only does it help to solve the issue of financing from the buyer perspective in that the cost could be shared by a group of people but it also solves the issue of expertise.  Meaning that some families may be interested in installing a toilet but have no idea how that might be accomplished.  To have an organization that publicizes their local knowledge and availability to assist in directing how a toilet would be installed might be the incentive a family needs to go ahead and initiate the steps required to get a toilet installed. I propose teaming up with existing projects such as : www.energyincommon.org so the choices/potential are more and wider for lenders/investors.For making administrative fees and transfer costs as low as possible.

chatter_boxes.description: A village in India features a successful toilet block design which allows womens' conversations to flow freely.
chatter_boxes.creator: 0ebfe65ca16ea82675e4294e27747639

comments.text: Providing people with a sense of safety seems vital in this. Open use public toilets need full-time on site maintenance/security staff to function well and discourage predatory and abusive behavior that often accompanies public toilets in populations affected by war, hunger and economic upheaval. Separating genders and having children go with the women is one traditional way of mitigating the dangers, but is not sufficient. Current public toilets are often filthy and could easily be injurious or even deadly for a small child through injury or illness.A woman probably will not bring their children to a place that is not safe, even to drop off or empty a waste bucket.Unless she has someone to care for the children while she is gone, she has no time to deliver her family's waste.
Also if privacy was an issue, you could have a mesh curtain that latches from one box to another.
I think some part of it can be covered , basically it can have door to some height that they can see each others faces to chit chat as you mentioned . Rather than keeping it fully open.

I couldn't imagine going to the bathroom without a door- because for me, it's kind of private. Additional social factors might include the need for separate bathrooms for females and males- for obvious reasons, but in certain cultures they may need to be completely separate so that the men don't ever see women entering or exiting.

This brings up a very important point. There may be social factors that bear on what is the best solution in a given location. I imagine that if there are a mix of different ethnic/cultural groups in an area where indoor toilets are not the norm, there may be several sets of customs around toileting that would be important to consider in designing hygienic human waste solutions. Gender differences in toileting customs are important too, as Meena has made clear.
Fascinating adaptation to local circumstances!

clean_insect_free.description:
Throughout our time here in Ghana we've heard many people express their concerns with bugs in and around their toilets. More tangible and understandable than invisible germs, flies, mosquitoes and maggots are often thought to be the true culprits spreading diseases.

The presence of bugs in public toilets is out of the control of their patrons, but we've found that owners of household toilets work hard to keep their facilities bug-free. In fact, when asked what they clean their toilets with, they almost always pull out a bottle of insecticide. The brands vary widely, as do their usage methods, but insecticide seems to play an important role in household sanitation in Ghana.

How might we communicate cleanliness in relevant and tangible ways (bug-free, as opposed to germ-free)? How might we ensure the proper use of chemical products when used in the home?
clean_insect_free.creator: dde2fb7aaee01b358a14703a9551c154

comments.text: Sanitation workers, just like hospital workers, need access to laundry and shower facilities. This necessity can also be a good incentive to take pride in maintaining cleanliness." I am a sanitation worker." can also mean I get to take a shower and wash my clothes after work every day, something few others can say in Kumasi.

Incentives for sanitation workers and the public to participate:--sanitation products, free toilet use tokens to give as gifts-- luxury foods with high cultural value such as coffee--bicycle, refrigerator, sewing machine or other coveted tools of affluence-- loan for business start up or education--uniforms for sanitation workers dispensed piece by piece as rewards for good service (include wearable medals or badges for exemplary service and make sure the uniform is gender appropriate for the cultural groups likely to work in sanitation)
Dis-incentives for santation workers to cheat-1st offense: A long lecture and tour of waste management facilities ( lecture subject--why what you did was a problem)2nd offense: Not getting paid and having to explain why what you did was not acceptable to your community (that way you still keep the job)3rd offense: Losing the job
I'll think more about dis-incentives for the public and owners of public toilets to cheat, and post as a separate concept.

Great comments, Sabra. These incentives for doing the right thing and punishments for doing the wrong thing really need to be thoughtfully designed. 
What other ways could we incentivize good behavior or discover/punish people who are cheating?

The idea of paying by the amount of waste collected has come up in several concepts now. I think it is a very good and important idea, one that will make all the difference in getting everyone's poop cleaned up.
Best to think about ways to discourage people from adding too much dirt or ditch water to the wastes to increase payments. The best ways I know to encourage honesty involve heavily incentivising desired behaviour and making it easy for the community to see when someone cheats the system.

bike_toilet_bikelet.description: I imagined a concept: allow access for people with mobility problems (disabled, elderly, pregnant women, etc…), it would adapt to changes in demand quickly, would be hygienic and clean (including for the planet), be low cost to everyone (including users) and a potential generator of employment and income. (The bike's image was created in an image editor! The prototype does not exist yet.)

comments.text: Look no further, we are Ecoloove an mobile ecological toilet company founded in 2007, helping women in rural areas and slum gain access to sanitation. Wired magazine has named us as one of the six most innovative sanitation project around. If you're interested in discussing mobile solutions email me on annamaja@ecoloove.com!

Great thoughts Alessandro. Food scraps from the restaurant would help make biogas production more efficient too. After going through the digester, the composted solids can be used to fertilize energy crops, cotton or other non-food money producing crops.

I believe there are several possibilities for the disposal of waste collected in this system. One thing I thought was in digesters constructed in various parts of the city. Connected to these digesters, would be constructed community restaurants, where the gas produced from the excrement would be used for cooking. People who provide the manure would be entitled to a discount, for example, 30% of the value of food, or... They could receive in the form of discount, the the same amount they paid for the use of Bikelet.

Thanks, Demian! I think that one of the most interesting features of this concept is that it allows the bathroom come up to you instead of you having to go to the bathroom. The Bikelet could serve a large area, several times a day. Serves well the elderly and people with mobility problems as it can get to the door of their homes. The placement of a portable toilet in a place require the user to go to that place. It would be necessary to build a small structure as well. This structure would require daily maintenance and cleaning. Are expenses that could be directed to the manufacture of one or two Bikelets. However, note that the concept is quite versatile, and your idea could be applied in some specific locations. Obrigado!

Great idea Alessandro! I mentioned this in evaluation but I will add it here also:Maybe the bike could drop off the empty porta-toilet at a spot and pick up a full one to take it to the processing center and then come back for the other toliet once it has been used for a couple hours.  Decoupling the toilet from the bike would make the operation more efficient, allowing the driver to service more porta-toilets instead of wait around for just one.(If this has already been mentioned in the comments please forgive me as I have not read all of them yet)Thanks again for the concept!
What can I say? PERFECT!Again, thank you, Vincent!

Just sharing something you all might find interesting in relation to company-sponsored mobile bike services. TriKademiK, operating in multiple locations in Ghana, is increasing school attendance of children that often have to walk long distances for education through free tricyle-based buses, funded by advertising sponsorship from companies like Zain Ghana (local mobile telecom operator) and Voltic (beverage brand owned by SABMiller). Outside of "schoolbus hours" the vehicle can be used for transporting other cargo (maybe toilets?). This points to the potential feasibility of the Bikelet, particularly around company sponsorship and the possibility of multiple uses/revenue streams. Find out more at: http://www.sociallyintelligentmarketing.com/products/8-trikademik  and http://springwise.com/weekly/2011-01-05.htm

Thanks, Vincent! I have tried to improve the concept every day, and I count on your support and all other openIDEATORS! Due to its mobility, the concept is able to adapt quickly to the needs of the population, according to time, place and habits. I'm looking for similar concepts on the internet but I do not have found anything with these characteristics.It is a concept 100% OpenIDEO. It is based on the inspirations from people like you.

Great concept Alessandro! Took me awhile to understand the potential. However, your refinements really helped make it clear. Not only does it increase accessibility and have transportation to treatment built right in, but it could also efficiently increase the # of people benefiting from/using each toilet by traveling wherever the need is throughout the day. For example, providing increased temporary toilets next to an existing public facility during the morning "rush hour", alleviating the current long lines and waits; then moving to a busy marketplace/workplace during the post-lunch afternoon; and followed by an evening run through the residential alleyways where no toilet facilities exist.
Yes! It is a COMPLETELY SCALABLE solution and can be implemented immediately, on a small scale.
Nice pictures! This design looks very much worth trying.
Thank you, Sabra! See the new picture added to. If you still have doubts, please write!
Washable fabric sounds wise. The tank empties by gravity? What does the tank empty into? What happens to the waste after it leaves the tank?

I imagine that the fabric could be made of nylon or polyester, easy to wash and dry and could be removed for washing periodically. I like organic materials also but would have to be replaced frequently and we need to consider the winds and rain.The pumping is not necessary, simply remove the tank and will come it (see the image of the reservoir which is also the floor of the cab).
http://www.appropedia.org/Category:CCAT_pedal_powered_innovations Some really great inspirations here.

Thanks Alessandro. I appreciate the extensions and clarifications. Woven sticks sounds beautiful, kind of like a big basket. How would that be cleaned?Crevices between sticks are tough to clean and inevitable urine spray or moisture from food waste would make the cabin smell bad really soon. Maybe you could do woven straw mats which are easily replaced and composted when they get soiled with food compost or human waste.Straw would also be a good addition to the composting process wherever the compost is made.Pedal operated pumping of waste would greatly reduce stress for the driver.

There is also a simpler way yet to make the tank ... A collecting box opened up, which was replaced by the driver at the end of the day by an empty and clean at the point of collection. This box would also be the bottom of Bikelet, and could be built in fiberglass or plastic. I'll try to make a sketch ...

Thanks Sabra! The image I have done is merely illustrative, but is also a tricycle! I have thought about how this whole thing would be lighter, ergonomic and stable. I think the cabin of privacy would be similar to an igloo tent, made of woven sticks and flexible, and fixed on the portable toilet. Thus, the center of gravity would be lower, improving stability of the tricycle. A good pair of mirrors would solve the problem of visibility on the road.I think if the tank could have a lid on the bottom, so the drain could be done by gravity. Another idea is that the reservoir could be pivotal, so that was opening up to the moment of use, and could be rotated, with the gap down to unload. I'll try to make a sketch and add the image.Avi, I think the project Zambulance a great success, so I believe the future has Bikelet! I think that due to weight, Bikelet often need to be discharged, but would be very stressful for the driver. So I think it would be better to make compost out of the bike.

I really like this idea, and I agree a prototype would be a great way to learn further about how it could work. I have a couple of concerns about the ergonomics and safety of hauling something the shape and weight of a person sized booth and waste storage bay. The zoomillion bike in related inpirations works because it is a trike, allowing the entire load to stay within the wheelbase and level with the force that's generated by the turning pedals. This makes the load easier to pull and creates no obstruction of vision in any direction relevant to observing traffic.Consider the additional possibility of making the privacy booth a set of folding screens around a portable squatter like the x-runner that feeds directly into the storage tank on the bike (or trike) via a pump operated by pedaling the bike in stationary position. A portable privacy screen keeps the action at nearly ground level, where it is more accessible for children, the elderly, etc. It's also less expensive, lighter and much easier to clean than a stall or booth (kiosk).

Alessandro, this reminds be of Jessica Vechakul's Bicycle Ambulance design at MIT:http://cadlab6.mit.edu/bike.ambulance/Maybe the MIT Zambulance design can be combined with the following portable composting toilet design to make a prototype of the Bikelet?:http://www.scribd.com/doc/45923633/Portable-Eco-Toilet-Patent

Like the way it is compared to taxis. The best would be if locals do it. These are low income households, and would give additional source of money to them. Maybe Unilever or the Govt. can help them with initial investment, and guide them on how to keep it clean and hygienic.Alongside the Toilet Taxi, these guys can also sell hygiene/sanitation products. When someone uses the Toilet Taxi, he/she could also be given tips on home hygiene and sold sanitation products. This could slowly increase awareness about such products.

One idea that occurred to me, reading the concept of Toilet Card, was that cards with a defined number of credits could be sold by the drivers of BIKELETS. For example, cards for 15 uses, for 30, 45, etc.. Instead of paying at the end of the month, you could pay in advance, according to his available cash.

It is possible, Jocelyn, provided that the components of the family reside at or near the same place. I find it easier to share the resource with the neighbors, residents of the same street. Imagine if every street had a mobile toalet these? And if she was not operated by a company, but one of the residents of the street? Residents could pay the operator for the service monthly, for example. Residents of the expenses of equipment (replacement of tires, etc.).. Also cost of cleaning supplies and paper and water Bikelet.If there was an industry to process the waste, part of the expenses could be paid by selling the waste to the industry.

I love it! Instead of bringing toilets to people, bring people to toilets! 
Are there other ways to think about leveraging toilets as a shared resource between families or compounds?

peepoo_bag.description: The Peepoo is a personal single use toilet (a poop bag), that sanitizes human excreta shortly after defecation, preventing the faeces from contaminating the immediate and larger environment.  It embraces existing 'flying toilet' behaviors.
peepoo_bag.creator: d814e015f931aba24d24c2f12025dc3c

comments.text: I like this idea a lot, because it works with the existing behavior (flying toilets) and transforms the action from a big problem to an opportunity for entrepreneurs.

Jeff- I had the exact same questions about this product when I talked with Anders Wilhelmson (architect/product designer).  This is some of the info I recovered from our short interview. The goal for the cost of the bags is to be depended on the buying power of the area (making it affordable for everyone). The bags have been tested in Bangladesh, and Silangra Kenya with positive results, Anders Wilhelmson said he has tested them himself (Im trying to get a hold of a few, if I am successful I will let you know how going goes). The bags can be kept in the house for up to 24-hours without smelling (also interested in testing).  One of the best aspects of the project is the social infrastructure being developed. Local women run all the sale and collection of the bags, and the Silangra Village community has been greatly involved with the introduction of the product.  It is not a final solution but a right now solution. This is a super brief comment; please let me know if you want more info! I also found a very in-depth pilot project report, and flickr images.

peepoo_bag.title: PeePoo Bag

considering_the_squat_toilet.description: Have had ample experience with squat toilets, due to travelling and living in places where they are prevalent. Though I prefer sitting, there are benefits to squatting as well. In fact, I have friends who, when using a sitting toilet, will always use a stool to best approximate the squatting position. The image is a sign from a Japanese city hall restroom directed at foreigners.

how_can_the_or_inform_how_we_deal_with_w.description: If you have ever been in the OR (operating room) you know the importance placed on what you can or can not touch if you are "scrubbed in". From washing your hands for 10 minutes prior to performing surgery to having to leave the room and start over again if you even graze something that is not sterile, the OR treats "waste" as a life and death interaction. How can we promote this same user attitude in every day citizens?
how_can_the_or_inform_how_we_deal_with_w.creator: f19c9fa069ffbf940afc53c378818dfc

comments.text: This is a provocative post Chris.  What comes to mind is the fact that also all the equipment in the OR has a life cycle, it is normally carefully planned where it comes from and where it will go after the operation.  Is it going to be sterilized? or is it going to be disposed, and how?  In other posts, we have been talking about composting, and also we are aware that not handling defecation properly might lead to diseases (i.e. defecation material buried close to a stream of water). Indeed food for thought.

how_can_the_or_inform_how_we_deal_with_w.title: How can the OR inform how we deal with waste?

giving_communities_their_rivers_and_stre.description:
I love this idea, not only is it mechanically simple but on a deeper psychological level it gives something that was lost back to the community...

Described as "Like a giant strainer dropped into the river," this concept is adapted from part of a proposed project from the architectural firm FAMILY, to build a floating pool in the rivers of new york (http://www.pluspool.org/ scroll down to water + pool). River water flows through panels of different material, filtering out pollutants and bacteria cleaning the river water while providing a safe area to use. An adaptation of this basic idea could instantly produce segregated areas of usable water in places where rivers and streams are completely overwhelmed by waste. 

Though this does not address the concerns of waste production, as other long term projects reduce waste that ends up in water sources these filters are slowly cleaning the water source as a whole.
giving_communities_their_rivers_and_stre.creator: 9126c258d96ec1e472380aa2851946bf
giving_communities_their_rivers_and_stre.title: Giving communities their rivers and streams back

dignity_and_community_building_through_p.description: The Ikotoilet facilities are highly visible, well-designed public toilets surrounded by retail and services in Kenya to combat "flying toilets" and pit latrines. It costs $0.07 to use the toilet and $0.20 to shower.
dignity_and_community_building_through_p.creator: dccfa7caab06f22e42985fc8f49c3201

comments.text: I've always had the personal view that paying to go to the toilet is a violation of human rights. There are other ways to fund the building and upkeep of toilet facilities. In this case there are the retail shops near the facility, the toilets would draw more potential customers to the shop location and increase sales. Alternatively, advertising space inside could fund the upkeep.

Good point about using the "high traffic" of such public toilets to create economic/community benefits. Also, these additional revenue streams can help provide financial sustainability for facility maintenance

dignity_and_community_building_through_p.title: Dignity and community-building through public toilets

comments.text:
Thanks Ashley. I'm completely overwhelmed by the idea that there is now a "place" where people can actually find value in my contribution on this level.
What do you think of my illustrations? They are intentionally low tech,(reflecting my actual skill level) but I think the symbolic content is valid and appealing. The middle thumbnail is an image I'd be honored if it could inspire signage to designate places to safely deposit flying toilets.

Hi Sabra, thanks for taking the time to write all of this out. I like how you've pushed beyond the Inspiration phase and really thought through some of the societal and systemic issues that might need to be addressed in this Concept. What I especially like is that you've considered human behavior in all of this, especially our tendency to react negatively to changes that are too far out of our current day to day (ie: thinking about how we can change behavior at little or no cost to the people doing the changing). I also like that you built on my example with Albina Ruiz and thought about how this concept could actually create new sources of income for entrepreneurs and business owners. Great work!

kopper.description: The Product named "Kopper" was developed as an Honours Project at UWS's Industrial Design Program. It is a sustainable hand washing device for the third world and areas struck by natural disaster. It converts contaminated water into highly effective anti-microbial cleaning agent by processing it through a filtration and electrolysis system. The system allows the user to clean their hands with approximately 5-20 ml of electrolysed water. To operate the device the user simply squeezes in the push pads and draws water through the filtration system. The Filtered water can then be pushed through the electrolysis system via the multi purpose hand pump/ push pads.
kopper.creator: 79d59e15a7ea854f33a921159447668c
kopper.title: Kopper

no_infrastructure_make_the_bathroom_the_.description: In poor areas with no drainage or waste removal infrastructure, bring a small-scale version of a sewage treatment plant directly to the public toilet location..
no_infrastructure_make_the_bathroom_the_.creator: 7c8e822d3f154bb2b046f6e1085eea54

comments.text: I love the idea of developing nodes of infrastructure in sequence. The Waterwall system of rain water storage and delivery uses a similar concept. Each section of fence is a water tank connected in series the whole length of the fence. Each tank has a spigot to deliver water where it's needed. http://www.waterwalltanks.com/

Sabra, Thanks for the comment!  Yes, thinking about the sanitation problem in relation to telephone communication infrastructure.  The problem with telephones that developing countries were dealing with only a few years ago was that of the expense of stretching telephone lines over great distances to reach only a small number of people.  This issue was overcome with the utilization of cellphone technology.  Now individual node cell towers could be installed more or less where they were needed and reached by satellite, thereby eliminating the need or the expense of running phone wires over long distances to connect the dots.The sanitation problem in some way feels the same.  With a lack of infrastructure to transport the waste over the long distance of the 'network', the most efficient solution would then be to install single nodes of sanitation processing where it is needed most.  Who knows, maybe these small sanitation processing nodes could be engineered so that their capacity could be added to in series as small scale waste drainage infrastructure organically branches out from the public facilities.  Priority might be to provide waste processing capacity to the nearby clinic, public school, etc.To think about waste processing in terms of nodes of organic growth may be a very viable way to develop this infrastructure. Thanks again for your comment Sabra!

Excellent concept Demian. Distills a complex problem to its essential simplicity. The work of sanitation professionals would be much less taxing and unpleasant, too. Reducing transport of waste as much as possible seems vital in all sorts of ways. The traffic increase inherent in transporting all wastes to one or even a few central processing facilities boggles the mind. Transporting finished compost would be much safer, saner and less expensive (weighs a lot less with the water taken out). A spilled load would be hard work to clean up, not a health hazard.However, you have to start somewhere. If vacuum trucks and a central landfill are available to work with, start there. Create the landfill as a waste treatment park and biofuels refinery. Make it an education center for community sanitation engineers.These community sanitation engineers can organize within each neighborhood and community to build the infrastructure and skills to treat waste in place as you suggest.

no_infrastructure_make_the_bathroom_the_.title: No Infrastructure? Bring Sewage Treatment to the Bathroom!

how_can_we_support_and_encourage_full_co.description: Incentives and disincentives are both necessary parts of engaging community cooperation with sanitation plans.  How can we use these tools to best serve the community in solving sanitation problems in Kumasi?
how_can_we_support_and_encourage_full_co.creator: 299453c107788839f427a6169f591ac4

comments.text: Sanitation workers should  have regular health checks and access to basic medical care, since they are at increased risk of contracting and transmitting waste borne disease. Access to medical care is also a good incentive for workers, as well as making their community value and status clear in a concrete way.
Advertising could sponsor murals by local artists and community chalkboards, too.

It is a good proposal and should be adopted in conjunction with any other which has the objective to modify the sanitation system itself. To be effective, this proposal should reflect the situation of public toilets. Workers clean > clean public toilets. New clothes > new health. Premiums for workers > prizes to users. To reduce the cost of this proposal, I suggest the inclusion of advertising of the sponsors on the products, uniforms, etc..

Good thoughts on increasing status of sanitation workers. If, in addition to removing human waste, they also brought valued items associated with their service (fertilizer, cooking fuel created from that waste; payment for poop; cleanliness calendar stars; hand sanitizer; etc.), this would also increase their positive perception and standing in the community.

One important way to decrease misbehavior is to increase community participation and benefit as much as possible. People will be less likely to cheat if they have participated in the whole sanitation process, and understand how cheating can damage its function. Education has proven to be much more effective than punishment in almost every situation. However, if people are accustomed to cheating as a way to survive, they may take a while to realize it is no longer to their benefit. Survival behaviors are difficult to change. We can't afford to discard people who are smart, capable and adaptable because they haven't yet learned how honesty can work in a cooperative system.
A teacher friend of mine was having a big problem with students from a specific nationality cooperatively cheating on college tests. He was going to great lengths to prevent cheating, but they were smarter than he was. I suggested he view this cooperative behavior as a resource and come up with a way to harness it. He started giving a sample final exam on the first day of class to show students what they were preparing for, and then suggested they form study groups to help them learn the material. Almost everyone got an "A" in the class after that, and they earned it.

how_can_we_support_and_encourage_full_co.title: How can we support and encourage full community cooperation with sanitation plans?

the_x_runner.description:
This is a really interesting urban slum sanitation concept . The X-Runner is a practical toilet and sewage system for the third world. The unit can flip up and be rolled, to a local Biogas Plant where it can be turned into electricity. 
Concept by: Noa Lerner
the_x_runner.creator: c186d344b513f4950e063174b5b150f4

comments.text: It looks like a great concept, but it isn't very big. Am I missing something?

Financially successful biogas programs make use of large amounts oflivestock manure mixed with human feces to maximize biogas production.Livestock manure will do just fine by itself, but human manure needs some help to perform. Even if there is not enough livestock manure available to really increase biogas production, it still makes sense to produce biogas, because it is such a cheap and effective way to sanitize and compost the feces.

Nice analysis Ossian. Gives us a better sense of the #'s we are dealing with, and what's currently realistic. Would be interesting to see how the figures work out based on local energy prices/demand in Kumasi. Also, anyone have any idea of the Ghana market for other human waste products like fertilizer?

Humans produce roughly 500 litres of urine and 50 litres of faeces per person per year. These contain about 4 kg of nitrogen, 0.5 kg of phosphorous and 1 kg of potassium, the three basic elements for plant growth. The exact amount varies from region to region depending on food intake. Seventy per cent of the nutrients excreted by humans are in the urine fraction.
Read more: http://wiki.answers.com/Q/How_much_excrement_does_the_average_human_produce_annually#ixzz19X811APf
The amount of biogas that can be yielded from human waste is limited in comparison with livestock manure and other feedstocks. Our stomachs are just too efficient! David House states in his excellent book that 1000 lbs (I don't know if this is urine and  and feces or just feces)of human waste produces about 0.6 cubic meters of biogas (enough cooking fuel for about 1 to 2 persons).
http://www.appropedia.org/Making_Biogas_from_Human_Waste
The price of natural gas varies greatly depending on location and type of consumer. In 2007, a price of $7 per 1,000 cubic feet (28 m3) was typical in the United States. The typical caloric value of natural gas is roughly 1,000 British thermal units (BTU) per cubic foot, depending on gas composition. This corresponds to around $7 per million BTU, or around $7 per gigajoule. In April 2008, the wholesale price was $10 per 1,000 cubic feet (28 m3) ($10/MMBTU).[39] The residential price varies from 50% to 300% more than the wholesale price. At the end of 2007, this was $12$16 per 1,000 cu ft (28 m3).[40] Natural gas in the United States is traded as a futures contract on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Each contract is for 10,000 MMBTU (~10,550 gigajoules), or 10 billion BTU. Thus, if the price of gas is $10 per million BTUs on the NYMEX, the contract is worth $100,000.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_gas
So 0.6 cubic meters of gas roughly equals $0.32. 
550 litres or urine and feces would weight around 550kg which would equal 1210lbs which would roughly give 0.7 cubic meters of buiogas which would roughly give $0.40. This is the average value of a years supply of sewage from one person given that human waste as defined by David House is urine and feces if not this number is roughly a tenth of that so $0.04. 

Ouch!
The $0.04 is probably more accurate as urine probably won't be collected.Can economies of scale make thias a viable job for someone. What is the average wage in some of the third world countries we're looking at?
I'm late for the cinema! Oops.

Could we have a version of the x-runner for sale in the developed world? It would make a great remote camping or off grid cabin toilet. Proceeds from its sale could easily fund making its purchase more affordable in the rest of the world....

The crux of this idea is turning human waste into cash, so the critical part of the chain seems to me to be the biogas plant. (My experience in many slum areas is that human waste currently flows everywhere - in pieces of waste land, on the railways, in the open drains outside people's homes - so the incentive to dispose of the human waste at the biogas plant needs to be real.) Hence, the vital part of the chain is the biogas plant. Anyone have any financial data on biogas plants, in terms of: payback from electricity sales - payback of capital investment - running costs = profit?
I second all of the previous comments. It's great that the whole ecosystem has been considered, and that the waste can be sealed inside for safe, discreet transport.
Wow, really simplifies the toilet down to its essence, so that its space saving, easy to transport for processing, and affordable...impressive.

Yes, I agree this is a beautiful project.  If someone is interested in supporting this project directly there is a way to do so through this website:  http://www.betterplace.org/projects/1805-x-runner-sanitation-social-business
I like that the entire product ecosystem has been considered and also that there are opportunities for entrepreneurial interaction.
This is a great concept. The small footprint this would take up in a house is really attractive.
