It's good but need a lot of work
Its got too many open questions right now to say either way

rebrand_the_experience_and_capitalize_on.description: Unmanaged open field toilet practice is a waste of resources and a missed opportunity. This 'natural' resource needs to be utilized!  Not only that, but the entire experience needs to be rebranded and re-presented so that the community does not ostracize it but, instead, embraces it as a vital resource to be capitalized on.
rebrand_the_experience_and_capitalize_on.creator: 7c8e822d3f154bb2b046f6e1085eea54

comments.text: I love the idea of combining the social actions with urban forestry. Few people think about it. The ambient of shantytowns could be much more enjoyable, is not it? Your concept reminds Arborloo, which is in Humanure Handbook (one of the inspirations). However, we must not forget that we are dealing with overcrowded urban areas. This is the Challenge. So this system may encounter some problems. The stormwater runoff in the major cities of the 3rd world countries is a serious problem. I do not think that Kumasi is the exception. So, if we use this system, we may have big problems in the rainy season. There is also the issue of groundwater contamination. Another problem in a big city and tight, is that these public toilets would be very close to the residences, which could be very uncomfortable for residents. However, I believe that the treated manure could be reverted to the afforestation of the city, helping to create awareness of the usefulness of the treatment of human manure. Something similar works very well here in my city, where the sewage is treated and returned as fertilizer for the public gardens.

Sabra, thanks again for your comments!Yes, changing the perception of societies to view waste as valuable is a very interesting idea.  This 'rebranding' effort could have very positive results.Thanks again!

Ossian, thanks for the comment!Very interesting thoughts!I agree that dealing with human waste is a complex, and potentially dangerous, issue.  And the entrenched perceptions surrounding it would be daunting to overcome.  But even great sea-changes in behavior can sometimes start out small.  An example could be the slowly changing perception of AIDS in many rural areas in Africa.  What was once a taboo subject, shunned and thought extremely dangerous is now more and more, through grass-roots public educational initiatives, being spoken about and dealt with openly in a more accepting fashion.  By doing the hard work of persevering against societal obstacles, AIDS activists have started to turn the tide of public misconceptions and awareness to be better able to help the victims and prevent further spread.Every change in behavior has to start somewhere and I think that this concept could be one part of the puzzle in striving for a solution.Thanks again!

Komaza http://www.komaza.org/ is a brilliant African social enterprise which specialises in micro-forestry. A key part of their approach is seeking to engage locals around their value proposition. I can imagine something like Komaza being a valuable partner in what you are suggesting  both in their relevant & specialised knowledge + local networks.

This is a very good idea. I like helping people see sanitation work as part of farming, and their own wastes as valuable.Most areas already in use as open defecation fields could begin the transition to farms almost immediately due to their enhanced fertility. Burying waste in pits and planting in the pits is 1000s of years old technology. It works extremely well in areas that don't flood or suffer from high water table. Making sure the pathogens in the pits are digested before the waste reaches the water table could be challenging,especially near water ways. I suppose it would be possible to build terraced raised farming beds and make "hill" latrines rather than pits at the core of each bed.

Sabra, Thanks for the content-filled comment!:)Yes, I think making even small changes in the experience as well as people's perceptions about existing behaviors has great potential.  The daily practice of pooping in open fields, on river banks, etc, typically considered an objectionable 'duty' and something to be shunned, could instead be seen as a renewable resource with great potential to be harnessed and utilized.  If the experience were organized just a little, I think public perception could be transformed.  Addressed from a slightly different angle, daily defecation of communities could be neutralized and used instead of left to pollute the ground and waterways.  With minimal setup, open field poop dumps could be 'rebranded' as farms.  Farms that benefit from the continual 'delivery' of fertilizer to grow plants that supply fibers or building materials to the community.  Imagine a row of outhouses on a wheeled platform positioned over a grid of shallow holes or trenches.  As people use the outhouses and fill the holes, the outhouses are then rolled a short distance to the next line of empty holes.  As noted above each used hole is treated and plants shoots are added.One of the main benefits of rebranding the entire defecation experience might be that the people employed in the human waste removal industry could be recast as 'farmers' instead of outcasts or untouchables.  This is a huge problem in societies that stigmatize certain types of work and shun the people that hold those jobs, relegating them to a lower class or caste.  If we are to overcome these issues, one way of addressing the problem could be to speak about the work in a positive way, as something necessary and vital to the community and it's well being.Another benefit might be that the use of the 'farm' facilities would be free.  The farming operation would welcome the fertilizer and could make money from the sale of the harvested building or textile materials.Speaking of the plants, I mentioned bamboo as an example of a plant that is not eaten (mature varieties anyway) but that is fast growing and useful as a building material or source of fibers.  But you are correct in that several different plant species could be farmed depending on the farm's location and indigenous plant life.Thanks again, Sabra, for your thoughtful comments!

I love the idea of a moving latrine, first dug then filled then moved. It could fit into a crop recycle.
How long would it take before land left for human sewage could be used for farms?
Does it mean that if you have a farm of a few acres that your toilet is, at times, next to your house and at other times a few minutes walk away. Neither seems all that desirable. And if it isn't desirable will it be used?
Extrement isn't clean and isn't nice to be around. In the first-world, those who work directly with sewage wear equpiment and protective clothing to protect themselves from the dangers and unplesentness of sewage. 
In the third-world this isn't possible. Working with sewage is dangerous and unpleasent. Where water, or soap and other disinfectants is scarce getting clean after working is difficult, costly and sometimes impossible. 
Can you rebrand an industry which has negative conatations associated with it for real reasons that sholdn't bwe ingored?
If the process was made clean, magically (for now at least), then a method of rebranding would be important to change cultural belief. Until then I don't see it working.

Some people call defecation duty, as in to do a duty, assigned work from a higher authority. As slang it makes sense. As long as we are alive, we must do it  almost every day. We are assigned this task by whoever put us here, and there is no escaping it.I think, why not make the best of it? Our own food and body waste can provide a source of clean power as part of the process of making it into safe compost which is perfect food for the soil.Everybody wins. I love the concept of going with existing behaviors. I imagine myself going out to the ditch/bank/field to defecate as people have been doing for generations untold and I feel the logic of it in my bones. We just have to adjust how people are doing it slightly, not where. Pit planting bamboo sounds good, although I have to wonder if there are native plants with just as much fiber potential we could be planting too or instead.Banana also comes to mind because of the many uses of the leaves and roots and how much shade it provides.I love the potential of bamboo as a building material. You can make really nice portable shelter, furniture, even paper and cloth from bamboo. You can do most of these with other fiber crops, but its potential as poles is unmatched.Responsibly designed above grade(so it can't spread) bamboo farms with planned harvest could produce large amounts of timber, tool handles, fiber or whatever really fast.Bamboo is a super invasive plant. To live with it, you pretty much just have to be picking all the shoots growing in directions you don't like. People who live in bamboo areas usually eat them. This would obviously not be an option for bamboo grown in human manure pits. Unchecked, it spreads and thickens, sucking up all the water it can, eventually crowding out most other life, including human.Clippings could be composted, but require ongoing labor input to maintain and prevent encroachment.Any area successfully planted in bamboo will never be available for any other use. Bamboo is permanent unless drought is so bad everything dies, and it spreads everywhere it possibly can.Where will people defecate 5 years from now? On the ground in between the bamboo clumps, because it's not possible to move an established bamboo clump or dig through its roots without heavy equipment or insane amounts of human labor with hatchets and saws. Eventually(10 years from first planting in a bamboo friendly place) there won't be room to site new latrines in between the root clumps.Harvesting poles has to be done very neatly, or the stump becomes a spear to the unwary foot. This is just what you don't need where shoeless people defecate.I've only lived around bamboo groves a little bit in Austin , Texas. That was enough to teach me not to go barefoot in areas where people have been cutting bamboo haphazardly. I asked a woman from the Philippines who grew up in a bamboo forest area how people kept from injuring their feet on the bamboo. She said people got hurt all the time and often got infections from the puncture wounds as well. She also said her parents taught her how to be careful and how to treat her injuries to prevent infection. Bamboo is marvelous stuff, but if you don't have the traditional knowledge to make it an acceptable neighbor, it can cause more problems than it solves.I'm very sorry this is so very long.Thanks for your patience to anyone who actually finishes this "comment".

rebrand_the_experience_and_capitalize_on.title: Rebrand the Experience and Capitalize on the Resources

smear.description: How can we equip/educate people to smear + keep hands clean?
smear.creator: f19c9fa069ffbf940afc53c378818dfc

comments.text: Vincent,"Smearing" is an often taught backcountry no-trace camping skill. This is how/where I learned it. I agree, it is incremental step, not ultimate solution. If one has to go outside, smearing is a relatively safe and clean option in reference to water supply and general public health.

Smearing seems like an incremental approach that would improve the hygiene associated with open defecation (good, in the sense that it's simpler and lower cost to implement; though more complete solutions might be better in the longer term). Chris, is smearing education actually being done successfully anywhere?

Johan,Thanks for your kindness in helping me learn to participate more gracefully here.Chris, I think if toilets were extremely low profile squatters with an efficient collection system, people could have their preferred open air experience and appropriate sanitation that works even in the rainy season

To Sabra, I am not really suggesting my ideas for extremely crowded urban area. the outskirts of cities where there is large farms are better. And i do not suggest every person walking into the field and crap in a hole. i suggest compost toilets in public user friendly bathrooms, and then a small company transport the material safely in sealed containers in a truck, and sell it to farmers.
and thanks for sending me a message to my facebook page, but i prefer if the discussion takes place here on the proper place.

The smear method above seems like an extremely good method of preventing disease in conditions of extreme crowding with no infrastructure available.Making toilets that people accustomed to going in the field will use and like is a worthy challenge. The Potty Project referenced above has impressive amounts of information about habits and customs around sanitation useful in creating "user friendly" public toilets.

But should we really want it to be blown away? It is loaded with nutrients that could be harnessed in farming.
The chemicals for producing industrial fertilizers are expensive and require long transports.
Lets come up with simple concepts that use the resource in the best way. Teach farmers and spread the info about the best practices on how to use compost toilets and leftover food as a source to get higher yield on crops.

smear.title: Smear

This keeps streets clean in busy nightlife areas. Urinals are removed late at night, emptied of contents, cleaned then brought back.

biocenters_toilets_showers_cooking_and_c.description:
An interesting solution in Kibera where multiple needs beyond sanitation are grouped together. Here individuals can use toilets and showers, but can also access the bio-gas (generated from human waste) for cooking and use the roof space for community meetings. The meeting space is particularly attractive since finding places to support groups can be difficult in the crowded informal settlements.

How might we bundle services together to make sanitation more desirable?
biocenters_toilets_showers_cooking_and_c.creator: 7c4937e9600c11ec07799e3463915c6d

comments.text: Very good idea ! But this cannot be the answer to a global solution at the scale of the whole urban area, isn't it only aimed to some random communities and therefore will create tension between communities ?
I love this idea especially about the bio-fuel. It's amazing how things can become so much more useful when used properly.
Laundry is one of the services offered at similar centers in India.

Wow very synergistic bundle (especially bio-gas for cooking). Also gives incentive for people to be responsible for toilet cleanliness: you want to maintain the place where your community meets and cooks.

Could we add a seat to it as we heard a preference for sitting toilets (rather than squatting)?

point_of_poo_pledge.description:
When are people most likely to relate to others’ sanitation problems? When they’re feeling the urge to relieve themselves of course!

Imagine if awareness/action-raising stickers/posters were placed on the inside of public toilet stalls in the developed world (from restrooms in schools to libraries to restaurants to gas stations; the possibilities are endless). As the toilet user reads the material to be distracted from the task at hand (just like people often have household bathroom reading material, or, in the case of some public toilets, check out the random scrawled phrases and pictures), they learn about sanitation issues elsewhere in the world and are referred to text a # to donate to help build hygienic, environmental public toilets where they are needed most, or for more information.

A similar campaign could also target tourists at the airport returning from countries with less developed sanitation systems. Please see below for example campaign text.

Image Attribution: http://xkcd.com/229/
point_of_poo_pledge.creator: b15ab3f829f0f897fe507ef548741afb

comments.text: Great idea Vincent! A second set of info in the corner of the bathroom mirror as a reminder, and further education moment would help people remember to" make the pledge". This one could say something about the unavailability of hand washing facilities.

Hi Sabra (and others that might be interested). I just came across an interesting bathroom mirror display technology currently active in 150 bathroom mirrors at the Chicago O'Hare airport, which I thought would be perfect for your bathroom mirror build.Basically, these mirrors normally display a fullscreen ad, but automatically sense when you are near (like the automatic on/off sink handwashing faucets), at which point the mirror becomes a regular functional mirror with a shrunk down non-intrusive ad in the corner, which you can still view if desired. While I was checking out these mirrors, I saw ads from Zappos, Geico, and some bottled water brand. Here's an article from the Chicago Tribune with more info: http://bit.ly/ej9J0w

After visiting China, I was confronted with vast amount of people that used the public streets for toilets. I read somewhere on this site, how everyone has a different idea of what clean is...Anyway in regards to the second reminder on the mirror what if the message was somehow connected to the water flow, if there was a delay in the start of flow if the water, somehow making the person washing their hands interact with the message sort of saying well you only had to wait a minute for the water and you were annoyed how would people in third world countries feel? technology is so clever these days....just a thought.
Sorry, wasn't clear on my fact about text message donations. What I mean to say was that text messaging of individual $10 pledges raised millions of USD$ to the Red Cross for Haiti disaster relief.

Thanks for the support and great builds! Agreed we should make action as easy as possible and nudge it along.
Alessandro, I did attempt to ensure on-the-spot convenience by allowing people to text a # directly with their cell phones (the donation charge would appear on their cell phone bills, a technique which raised millions of USD$ through $10 donations). However, your right that other easy ways to donate (such as calling a # as you suggest) would also make sense.
Sabra, the mirror/sink idea is a great way to further educate, increase pledges, and broaden the issue!

Hey, Vincent! Great idea!The text was also very good. I think that Unilever could finance this campaign.But I have an idea to add:You're sitting on the toilet and in front of a poster speaks of sanitation problems in Ghana. How to convince you to contribute financially to the campaign? Telling you visit the website "x" and see the project? No! Upon exiting the bathroom, you would forget about it! I would take advantage of the timing and impact of the poster and tell you to pick up your phone and call, for example, 0800-000-0010 to donate $ 10, 0800-000-0015, to donate $ 15, etc.. What do you think?

challenges_around_water_access.description: In many low-income urban areas water is not free-flowing. Worth reflecting on for those of us who are used to just turning on a tap.
challenges_around_water_access.creator: 0ebfe65ca16ea82675e4294e27747639

comments.text: In areas where rainfall is so extremely seasonal that storage has to be ridiculously large to meet dry season needs, it may seem that the infrastructure costs are too high to make rain water catchment viable. However, the water will always be needed and rain doesn't have to be brought in trucks. If you look at all the current costs of dealing with water delivery and any seasonal floods, I suspect  large capacity storage begins to look much more viable. It's definitely a long term investment, no doubt about that. I'd suggest as a first project, creating rainwater diversion and catchment for the landfill area. That reduces pollution at the same time as it provides a new source of clean water to use in waste processing/crop irrigation.

Thanks Meena, I'll do my best. Today I'm thinking of all the people who already own public toilet businesses. Whatever we do in Kumasi should minimize disruption to them. Even positive change can create unwanted effects like destabilizing the local business economy. Providing opportunities and support for existing businesses to make changes they feel necessary seems like a respectful choice. Taking pieces of the puzzle not currently addressed and minimizing direct competition also seems wise.

Interesting thoughts Sabra. Somewhere like Dharavi has no rainfall except for the few months of monsoon  so storing water would involve *major* infrastructure. Not sure about the situation in Kumasi. Looking forward to you fleshing out your ideas more in the Concepting phase  perhaps with some kind of diagram of what you propose.

How can we use the process of sanitation to leverage water access for people in Kumasi?
Even in areas of low rainfall, significant amounts of water can be collected off rooftops during the rainy times, if there is somewhere to store it until it is needed.Simple calculations based on average seasonal and annual rainfall will tell you how much roof area would be necessary to provide for some or all of the water needs of the population using each latrine or toilet.Every toilet or latrine needs a roof to protect it from the weather.Along with whatever tank is used to collect the waste, each latrine or toilet could have a rainwater tank.If rainwater catchment was created as part of the sanitation infrastructure, then drinking water (always the first priority) and water for personal hygiene and clothes washing would be much more available.I love the synergy potential for being able to get my drinking and/or shower/wash water from the place I take my wastes to be disposed of. Water in, water out...One stop shopping makes for less trips=more time for other things in life.Capturing rainwater also aids sanitation in urban areas by reducing runoff into streets, streams and rivers. Water from people washing themselves and their clothes can also be used to irrigate crops, further reducing runoff, and creating another source of livelihood for people in the area.If you maximize the potentials for generating revenue and social capital from the sanitation process you can leverage all sorts of other positive changes that impact quality of life.Human waste is the most undervalued resource on the planet. It is also among the most abundant, and therefor cheapest. People will actually pay you to take it away...
Even if there is a waterless toilet (think moldering privy) the users might enjoy a refillable water spray can for that extra touch of luxury - there's lots of space here for bottom-up innovation:)
Good point about the potential limitation of water accessibility Meena. Something I hadn't fully recognized till your post.

Great insights, Meena! We've heard a number of people in Kumasi say that water is a scare and expensive resource and they would rather not have to use it to flush their toilets. Thinking about waterless or low-water solutions is certainly important.

smart_bags.description: Smart bags is an innovative product, which can be disposed of in lavatory units, then sealed tight after each use.They appear much like larger airsickness bags with integrated glue strip to seal close. One-use-only bags, avoids further contact and illnesses.Then,are shipped together with other bags to a local wastewater plant where its processed.Sludge can be reprocessed into biosolids that could serve as fertilizer for local farms.Residual water could be used for other non-food activities.Methane gas extracted from the feces can be used in peoples homes. One plant can serve many rural communities, and valuables coming from previous wastematerial will become available to those communities.This is a smart way of getting rid of feces,without it ending up in disease prone landfills.Smart Bags increments salubrity in rural areas that dont have proper sewage facilities, while also opening a gap for return potential benefits.Smart bags are made of resistant biopolymer materials which makes them 100% biodegradable.
smart_bags.creator: 3ca5ffaaf2e9c63910d13186fea3c935

sanitary_with_vacuum_extraction.description: Toilet without separation of feces and urine. The manure will be extracted by the vacuum equipment. The city of Kumasi already has equipment and workforce that could do the job of extracting the waste. The toilet has a plastic cover movable, which opens and closes automatically during use. This lid is intended to hide the manure and reduce the smell.
sanitary_with_vacuum_extraction.creator: 155a2e9ba2686b27dfccb0ab6b2034ee

comments.text: I said, this concept, the possibility of doing the manual removal of waste. Adriana Olmos spoke of a hand pump that would serve well for the concept, with minor adaptations.See: http://bit.ly/f3oTVP

Yes. I have thought of a toilet with limited capacity, and possessing a tube with cover, through which the contents of the toilet can be extracted quickly. I do not believe in something as time consuming and expensive cleaning of the pit. I think of something like a pitstop. The hose should have vacuum equipment or a perfect fit with the outlet pipe of the toilet, so the hose does not need to be introduced into the tank of the toilet, but only embedded in the output of the tube, like a fire hose. Then, the equipment is connected and the vacuum created sucks the contents of the tank.This would allow a truck quickly walk down an entire street.
This is a great idea. If the capacity of the toilet is limited, the base could be emptied by a service provider or by the family into a depot point which then the vacuum truck could pick up from.
Thanks! I hope to contribute new ideas and with new interpretations of things that already exist in the world.
Welcome Alessandro  great use of an online translator to join us here. And your visualisations speak loud and clear across languages  nice one!

what_can_we_learn_from_the_past.description:
From below it can be seen that marketing of the toilet is what made Crappers products famous. The image was taken from a pub in Chester, original marketing print.

Contrary to widespread misconceptions, Crapper did not invent the water closet. He did, however, do much to increase the popularity of the toilet, and developed some important related inventions, such as the ballcock. In the 1880s, Prince Edward (later Edward VII) purchased his country seat of Sandringham House in Norfolk and asked Thomas Crapper & Co. to supply the plumbing, including thirty lavatories with cedarwood seats and enclosures, thus giving Crapper his first Royal Warrant. The firm received further warrants from Edward as King and from George V both as Prince of Wales and as King.
what_can_we_learn_from_the_past.creator: 80fa1bf5dc7b7b6f55e54661b4ca5a0d

comments.text: Very interesting! .. Thanks for sharing. On similar lines, one can learn more about the history and evolution of toilets by visiting the "Museum of Toilets", run by Sulabh International a non-profit organization that has pioneered some very innovative sanitation initiatives in India and across the world. Here is their website: http://www.sulabhtoiletmuseum.org/

what_can_we_learn_from_the_past.title: What can we learn from the past?

luxury_public_restrooms_funded_by_compan.description: Building on Anna's "Fund it with Advertising" inspiration, Charmin toilet paper has been sponsoring public restrooms in the US as a marketing activity for years, rolling up to big public events with their luxury freestanding and mobile restrooms. For example, right now, there are 20 public Charmin restrooms in the heart of New York City: http://www.charmin.com/en_US/enjoy-the-go/nyc-restrooms.php

comments.text: Are there low-cost ways to connect a bio-digester to a latrine to capture bio gas and use it for cooking as an energy source for other things?

Anyplace that has room for a latrine has room for a family scale biodigester.Larger systems do take up some room, but not any more than whatever they replace. I don't know the cost comparisons, but I think since this is a solution of choice in India and China it must be pretty cost competitive.

What's the cost of implementing this biodigesters?You need someone to coordinate, raise funds, you need proper space (some very poor communities do not even have space available)... How operational is this idea for a broad adoption?If the "implementation" questions are answered, I think it's a great idea.

texting_toilets.description: This builds on the observations by the OpenIdeo Ghana Field Team that “in just about every home there [were] cell phones (one or two per family member)” and Andy’s remark that “there’s more cell phones than toilets in Africa”, as well as building comments and additional inspirations by Ashley and others (linked to on the right side). Given the situation, this concept leverages widely available/used mobile phones to improve toilet hygiene and access. Potential labor cost-savings could also be invested to lower usage fees, improve facilities, or build new toilets.
texting_toilets.creator: b15ab3f829f0f897fe507ef548741afb

comments.text: If each cabin, inside it, had a registration number, the user could take a picture with his cell phone. In this photo, it should display the registration number and (in the same picture) the dirt from the site.The user would send the photo to a central. The picture would be evaluated and if it were confirmed to bad conditions of use, steps would be taken. I know are still not all people who own phones with cameras, but it is a technology that is gaining popularity very fast, and increasingly low cost.

Excellent point about accurate trusted tracking and charging for unclean toilets Demian. If the false positives for unclean toilets is too high or too often assigned to the wrong person, this system would fall apart. I do think this challenge is surmountable though, perhaps as outlined below.
I had a related concept that relies on attendant verification (and doesn't require cellphones) here ( http://bit.ly/ebfxYs )...maybe a blending of these 2 approaches would work best.
Also, another method of decreasing false reports is to require the current user to report uncleanliness immediately upon opening the toilet (say replying to the unlock confirmation text message within 40 seconds, thus ensuring the he/she did not have time to use the dirty the toilet and then report it as unclean). He/she will then be switched to a clean toilet and avoid any potential charges, while the unclean toilet is automatically locked. Then the previous user (who left an unclean toilet after use) is only charged when the maintenance worker arrives and verifies that the toilet is unclean. Phone #'s that have too many false reports, or too many cases of not cleaning the toilet after use, could also be automatically banned from the system for a set period of probationary time. This is similar to the reporting system that is used by Zipcar  (largest on-demand car sharing/renting in the United States) to ensure that cars are in good condition after each use.

Vincent, great ideas! Pricing is key.  A small amount to use the toilet but a large amount added if it is left uncleaned?  The one issue I could see with that model would be that there might be a lot of disputes from people who were charged but protest that they actually cleaned the toilet after their use.  Maybe to minimize the disputes the on-sight bathroom attendant verifies that the room is clean before the person that just used it leaves.  That way, if there is an issue with the state that it is left in it could be resolved right then and a penalty cleaning fee would not be subtracted from their account.  Also your idea about a text alerting a maintenance crew or attendant is a good one.  A system that is updated in real time by all of its users would probably be the most efficient on a tight budget.  Lots of potential here.Thanks Vincent!

I really like this concept.  Especially how it incentivizes people to clean the toilets after use.  Though... I am not sure that everyone would do it even if charged extra.  And then people entering a toilet to find it dirty would be less inclined to use it knowing that they would have to clean up more than just their usage.  So there would definitely have to be mobile maintenance workers that would clean toilets that had not been cleaned by the users.  But, maybe the model could be tweaked a bit to make it all work... I like it!  Thanks Vincent!  A lot of great ideas here!
Here's a bunch of Healthcare texting strategies that can be adapted for Sanitation:http://mobilehealth2010.org/node/9http://mobilehealth2010.org/node/10

Thanks for the inspiration and the builds Ashley! Funny thing is, despite having previously worked for P&G (the consumer products company behind Charmin) in marketing/brand management, I knew about the Charmin luxury public toilets but was unaware of the new app.
As for the Project Masulileke reference ( http://www.poptech.org/project_m_the_solution ), that really helps demonstrate the feasibility for this type of concept, as well as showing how to take it further. You're absolutely right about adding an educational component for these texts. For example, you could see short tips being added to the end of regular service messages that the user can then follow up on to receive more information.

Love this idea! And thanks for the shout out to my previous comments :)I thought I'd add a link to a great example of a PopTech initiative called Project Masulileke, a texting campaign in South Africa to raise awareness about HIV/AIDS. Check out the whole campaign here: http://www.poptech.org/project_m, or read just about the specific texting aspect of it here: http://www.poptech.org/project_m_the_solution.Perhaps there could be an educational component to the service texts you're proposing, where we can use cell phones to provide basic education about sanitation, waste disposal, and general cleanliness?

waste_collection_through_community_empow.description: What I love about Ashoka Fellow and social entrepreneur Albina Ruiz and her Ciudad Saludable (Healthy City) initiative is that she refuses to accept that anyone should live surrounded by garbage, filth and potential disease. Albina has made it her mission to help communities clean up their own neighborhoods in Peru, especially in the poorest areas where people rummage through the trash and try to resell items to support their families. Interestingly, Albina doesn't just work to clean up the trash. She recognized that taking away the trash, while it would improve living conditions, also meant taking away vital income that these communities needed to survive. So, she worked directly with people in the community and gave them jobs going door to door to collect trash. Instead of just taking away the garbage, she gave people access to income and dignified work that bettered their communities and their families.
waste_collection_through_community_empow.creator: 884b3f632f6af8e3f87b26795b8a4f31

comments.text: Garbage is "wealth", this is inspirational what people call garbage can be used to get money if utilized in a proper manner.We have used the same approach here in Uganda where garbage disposal and management is a responsibility of the community.Garbage is collected,sorted and used to make many things like charcoal briquettes,crafts,bio-gas,compost manure hence creating employment opportunities for the youth and women to earn a living.This can be a great idea for garbage and other waste management to improvement.
I think this idea is really a key one. People are getting respect and getting paid for cleaning up the wastes. Sustainable livelihood and self respect go hand in hand.

Hi Sabra, I'm so glad you liked this idea. Albina seems like such an amazing woman and I was so impressed by her and her commitment to empowering communities to help themselves. And you're so right - her program has not only helped clean up neighborhoods; it's given people a sense of pride and respect for themselves and their homes.
Ashley, thank you for sharing such a perfect inspiration. When people can take pride in their participation in making their community a clean and healthy place, they practice self respect.

waste_collection_through_community_empow.title: Waste Collection through Community Empowerment and Relationship Building

compost_maintenance_service.description: The Daily Dump provides home composting systems-- including clay pots to collect and compost food waste, an optional service to maintain the composting process, and 'crisis visits' to help people when they've created a composting mess. What if latrines had a range of service options for regular maintenance and crisis management? http://www.dailydump.org/

comments.text:
First, these are the most beautiful home composting pots I've seen, especially compared to the roto-molded industrial-looking bins I usually think of.
Second, the idea of tying in food compost and waste compost is very interesting!  From a system perspective, I like Sally & Jocelyn's extension of these types of services to sanitation waste.  From a perception perspective, I like merging the thinking of all these different kinds of wet wastes into a single stream of household material that has to be managed.
This is a really good model that could be used for all sorts of things. (Like popularizing any sort of home eco-tech)

Very interesting. Also like how they have a process for like-minded enterprises to "clone" The Daily Dump (spreading the impact while providing business opportunities): http://www.dailydump.org/clone_daily_dump
The Daily Dump is designed to quickly compost waste. Could it work for people to compost their own human waste at home? Seems like it could be worth a shot.

comments.text: Wow, great inspiration with such a large, multi-faceted impact!

Harvesting and selling biogas creates a source of revenue to finance building more public restrooms. The process of making the biogas also kills all pathogens and deodorizes the solids. These solids are now safe to use as fertilizer, and they don't even smell bad anymore. Taking the process of cleaning up human and animal waste and using one of the cleanup steps to produce clean fuel has got to be one of the most important ideas on the planet right now. Residue from biogas production is compost and water.

comments.text: Attended multi-use centers such as this would help in providing a vital sense of safety for the people using them. Designing the "one stop shops" to be safer for small children, perhaps with some sort of childcare/supervision available for children whose parents are transacting recycling business or using the facilities, would make them more accessible to families. This could also be a good opportunity for family sanitation education.

I wrote this in my evaluation:
Letting local construction company design and build it.
Making a local competition for a name of this concept.
Making a public tender announcement to let many small local business owners/contractors send in yearly offer for the right to lease it and pay rent.
And also making a monthly or yearly fee for international producers of cleaning products for the right to be on a shelf inside the shop. So that local competitors could be given equal size of shelf space cheaper or for free.

Great idea, Brady! Building on the idea of a one-stop shop, we saw a need for consolidation in the sanitation construction process in Kumasi, and it'd be great to have a "One-Stop Shop" for home sanitation as well. For example, rather than going to a 5 different vendors and contractors for 5 different parts of the product/service (each of whom marks up their products), it'd be great to have one place that sold it all (tanks, seats, pipes, bricks, etc.).

This would be especially nice especially as the supply chain is so disconnected for sanitation products in Ghana. Combining all the necessary purchases to one place and even linking them to the service would certainly make things easier for the consumer.
This reminds me of Eco Toilet's model in Nairobi which has been quite effective. This seems to work especially well in public markets or other public areas.

ecological_dry_toilets_at_pedregal.description:
A cheap and efficient method which saves water and produces good quality compost. Urine is separated from solid waste with a simple design. Rather than use water, a mix of 3 soil to 1 ash (kept in a bucket beside the toilet) is added on top of the solid waste, building instant compost.

This is one project in a series of soil conservation, groundwater recharge, and farming demonstration projects at Pedregal a Permaculture Demonstration Center in San Andres Huayapam, Mexico.
ecological_dry_toilets_at_pedregal.creator: d7d03fc4ed767b64ad78b2fdbcd6324c

comments.text: Or ash over sawdust in this case. Sawdust was available in quantity. Ash was not. Ash kills flies and fly eggs. Sawdust pile has to stay really hot to kill everything you want to kill.
Great to get comments from personal experience, Sabra! Sometimes things read well but it's through actually using them that we can determine issues like the preference for sawdust over ash.

I lived in a community in southern Missouri that uses a similar system, but with sawdust instead of ash. Ash works better. These sorts of composters are simple to operate and maintain. In areas where population is not consistently high enough to maintain biogas production, such as out in the fields in rural areas, these sort of toilets are ideal. They can be made much more simply than the beautiful example above in areas where these building materials are not available.

ecological_dry_toilets_at_pedregal.title: Ecological dry toilets at Pedregal

It’s a new public toilet accessible by code from SMS and work with the energy from plasma gasification technology and pyrolysis processes that convert almost any waste material into usable product as green energy.

comments.text:
Great inspiration, Sara. Would love to see others build on this and add some more concepts. 
Are there any concepts related to dry toilets using plantain tree leaves? Or adaptation of cruise ship toilets for household use? Or a model that builds on Curitiba's waste management system?

uddt_urine_diverting_dry_toilet_explaine.description:
The UDDT toilet is built such that urine is collected and drained from the front area of the toilet, while faeces fall through a large chute (hole) in the back. Depending on the Collection and Storage/Treatment technology that follows, drying material such as lime, ash or earth should be added into the same hole after defecating. Men, as well as women, need to sit while urinating to ensure that the urine is diverted into the correct channel.
Source: http://www.akvo.org/wiki/index.php/Urine_Diverting_Dry_Toilet
uddt_urine_diverting_dry_toilet_explaine.creator: c186d344b513f4950e063174b5b150f4

comments.text: Merci Jocelyn, I am finding this is a really interesting topic to learn and discover.
Thanks - this is great. We're looking for innovative, low-cost toilet designs and this is really good inspiration.

uddt_urine_diverting_dry_toilet_explaine.title: UDDT (Urine Diverting Dry Toilet) explained

poo_on_your_poo_gardiner_ch4.description: Loowatt is a innovative toilet concept meant for developing nations that's made entirely out of recycled feces. Designed by Virginia Gardiner at the Design London Imperial College, Gardiner created the toilet in response to seeing the need for reused energy in the human waste process. Gardiner calls the Toilet the Gardiner CH4.
poo_on_your_poo_gardiner_ch4.creator: b5b27164c4d69ef639000ffda01bed89
poo_on_your_poo_gardiner_ch4.title: Poo on your Poo - Gardiner CH4

_better_sanitary_protection._period._.description: I was first introduced to Sustainable Health Enterprises (SHE) back in 2009 at The Feast Conference in New York. Elizabeth Scharpf, founder of SHE, presented to the audience the innovative work her organization is doing to help women and girls in developing countries obtain access to low-cost sanitary pads. SHE calculated that women and girls miss up to 50 days per year of work or school because they cannot afford the sanitary pads they need. Not only do they miss school or work, but these women who can't afford pads also end up turning to unhygienic and ineffective solutions like rags or tree bark to use instead.
_better_sanitary_protection._period._.creator: 884b3f632f6af8e3f87b26795b8a4f31

comments.text: Thanks for pointing out a great innovation, and local enterprise.
What a great campaign! Thanks for sharing that Ashley. I am checking it out more now at http://www.sheinnovates.com/

India has launched a massive government supported programme to develop low cost-quality sanitary pads. I visited one in Gujarat, India and talked to the women operating the unit. Its a launch and will see how it works out. As an enterprise, women would need a lot of hand holding and support simply because they are first have to play the multitude roles - wife, mother, sister, daughter-in-law, daughter, neighbor and then an entrepreneur! Plus to fight the secrecy that veils the whole process of menstruation.

Svava, I'm glad you enjoyed the video. I found it particularly inspiring. And Courtney, I'm pleased you already know about SHE. I have been so impressed with their work and thought this would be a terrific venue to promote their mission.
Thanks for sharing the inspirational video. Girls and women especially have to be considered when thinking about sanitation solutions.

I love Sustainable Health Enterprises and their life-changing mission.  The launch pads are an amazingly innovative product design (Elizabeth is in Rwanda right now for the ground breaking of the pad factory -check the pictures of facebook: http://www.facebook.com/#!/SHEnterprises) but what I think is more crucial to the success of SHE is the implementation of their mission. Because of the taboo of menstruation there was no communication between daughters and fathers (traditional the money keepers) about the necessity for buying pads. The last few years SHE has been in Rwanda doing awareness talks, parades, and working through established health channels, and really changing the social views of menstruation.  In addition to the pad, social taboos are being confronted which is an amazing feat, which will have lasting change.

_better_sanitary_protection._period._.title: "Better Sanitary Protection. Period."

remediation_park.description: The Phoenix Project takes the latest technology and applies it to create Remediation Parks that transform pollutants and toxic wastes into useful products. Wherever there is garbage, municipal wastes, sewage or toxic pollution of any kind, the Remediation Park provides a way to retrieve anything of value and turn the rest into energy. It can handle everything, even nuclear wastes, in a perfectly safe way. The only thing that comes out of the Phoenix Project is a stream of new products and electrical energy
remediation_park.creator: 3162a04a0b81bc677801cdecb83df486
remediation_park.title: Remediation Park

constructed_wetlands_for_wastewater_trea.title: Constructed Wetlands for Wastewater Treatment

This seems like a good solution already in place in the homes. If people can be motivated to bring all the wastes to the public toilet, and develop the skills and means to keep the "bathroom" clean, this solution is a great partner for public toilets.

making_sanitation_a_game_.description: Child Rights and You (CRY) – has launched an online Snakes and Ladder game to raise awareness about the challenges faced by rural schools. The game includes messages about water and sanitation. A ‘ladder’ will advance you quickly towards your goal – a school that is close to home, or has clean drinking water; a ‘snake’ will hinder your progress – like no separate toilet for girls and boys, or no free government school in your village.
making_sanitation_a_game_.creator: be79583f5180581691d1d0be1699b621

comments.text: This is great Jocelyn! And something like this could go a long way in highlighting less obvious issues of hygiene (as noted in the recent Potty Project key takeaway: http://bit.ly/gHu99J )

making_sanitation_a_game_.title: Making sanitation a game

space_constrained_bathrooms_.description: A very small toilet and sink in a jail cell at Alcatraz. This made me think about what we could learn from bathrooms designed for small spaces.
space_constrained_bathrooms_.creator: be79583f5180581691d1d0be1699b621

comments.text: Everything about our bathrooms should be rethought.  There's no reason to pee into bowls of fresh water, then use another gallon or so to wash into our waterways to cause algae blooms and dead zones. And now that we know that an aerosol mist is created when you flush feces that will float around the bathroom and land on everything, I think it's time to switch to composting toilets. And if we must keep using water, why not use the water we just bathed and washed hands in?
Avi, your links to "The Potty Project" research are great...lots to learn from them. Perhaps you could post it as a separate inspiration?

Jocelyn, your questions reminded me of my childhood experiences wandering through the chawls (tenements) in Mumbai. Access to dignified sanitation is a basic human right. You should check out the absolutely stellar work being done on exactly this topic by the good people at The Potty Project in India:http://www.slideshare.net/thepottyproject/insights-preview-the-potty-projecthttp://pottyprojectindia.tumblr.com/

great points, i'm guessing what we can't see but can imagine is that the cell is probably very small as it is, and probably shared with another inmate. imagine the social rituals that get created, how they might avoid certain times of the day, before lights out etc

space_constrained_bathrooms_.title: Space-constrained bathrooms

unsafe_dumping.description: In Ghana, we’ve seen that many public and private latrines empty directly into the gutters that run parallel to the streets.
unsafe_dumping.creator: dde2fb7aaee01b358a14703a9551c154

comments.text: It might make sense to pay even individuals who use public toilets a small amount for depositing wastes there. This would make children's waste worth collecting and disposing of appropriately. In slums outside Curitiba, Brazil they have paid people in food to collect garbage in areas trucks cannot reach.

l would like to agree with Sabra, waste management is the community responsibility which requires and external support for guidance.when people are sensitized and know their role in solid waste and other human waste management its management becomes easy.its true that public toilets should be used with a little fee for maintenance agreed by the common people who use them. If the prices are dictated by the external people it makes the users resistant because they have no ownership.Therefore this ideas should be clearly modified to enable sustainability.When the fee charged is high,the slum people will improvise by littering human waste in drainage channels and also come up with flying toilets during nights where waste is disposed in polythene bags and throw then on top of other peoples houses which increases vulnerability to diseases.

In one way, I think, primarily it is necessary to make discussion with people around the public bathroom, who are using it and affected directly by those unhealthy practices. Discussion brings the local level solution of disposing into ditch or putting into dustbin as well as ensures the direct involvement of people to brings better ideas of healthy practices, such as making local level sanitation monitoring committee. The Committee follows and monitors about practicing the local system as well as putting them into designated areas as well. On the other way, We have to make sense of paying some to individuals as well as surrounding people, so that they can manage a dustbin as well as they can spend it to make gutter clean. And this kinds of money contributes to cover the gutter properly.
Great ideas Jamie + Sabra  hoping you'll be putting these together for us in detail during the Concepting Phase which will be starting next week!

I think people love competing, maybe we can ask that community to design a functional latrine. We will give them this requirements....safe and clean disposal service. Whoever comes up with a good design, the team will win something like house improvement, a park in their area or additional chairs or classroom that is near their area.

Pay people to deliver waste appropriately for composting or biogas production. Waste collectors purchase or lease a rolling container or cart to transport the waste safely. (like the x-runner) The messiest places are the ones that people can earn the most cleaning up and educating people (like Waste Collection through Community Empowerment and Relationship Building)

unsafe_dumping.title: Unsafe Dumping

linking_cause_and_effect.description: Making the connection between sanitation methods and the safety of water is a challenge when the water just looks so appealing. Many communities just ignore the safety of their water source and use it anyway.

comments.text: I wonder if people could be inspired to imagine what it would be like to have their children only get sick 1/10  as often? Is this too far out of their experience to be real? What if no more babies died of water borne illness? The life of our children is a strong motivator.

linking_cause_and_effect.title: Linking cause and effect

integrated_systems_management.description: Build a network of pay toilets where the waste was collected and processed in a biodigester on a farm. The biogas is used for food preparation and or electricity production. The nutrient rich effluent is then used as fertilizer for algae ponds. The algae is dried and fed to tilapia who are connected to a hydroponic system of vegetable production.
integrated_systems_management.creator: d96ceb0bfa46cd4291a51a72be6057e1

comments.text: The process for creating energy (biogas or urine fuel cell) is part of the process of sanitizing the waste. Biogas is easy, cheap to produce and returns most of the carbon to the soil as clean compost. Urine powered fuel cells sound like an excellent companion technology once it is perfected.

integrated_systems_management.title: Integrated Systems management

unibox_process_turning_problems_into_opp.description: Have you thought about how to bring the toilet into the homes of Kumasi? Small houses, mostly with a single room?
unibox_process_turning_problems_into_opp.creator: 155a2e9ba2686b27dfccb0ab6b2034ee

comments.text: Great concept and very close to a few of the concepts we're thinking about for the Ghanasan project. Great thoughts on how to incorporate Unilever into the solution with the use of an air freshener. The affordable in-home toilet is also a critical piece of the solutions we're looking for. And, the service element is vital to ensure that waste is not dumped in the gutters or the local bodies of water.

unibox_process_turning_problems_into_opp.title: UNIBOX process: turning problems into opportunities.

white_tiles_clean.description:
In Emenaa, outside Kumasi, Ghana, we visited Matthew who installed a latrine last year with a toilet-bowl top in his house for his family and tenants. The “bathroom”, a white-tiled room for bathing with a bucket is located next to the room with the toilet, a bucket for “flushing” and a basket of newspaper for wiping. 

When we commented on the cleanliness of the two rooms, Matthew jokingly remarked that it was Italian tile that he had used and that he had paid more for it to look nice and be clean
white_tiles_clean.creator: dde2fb7aaee01b358a14703a9551c154

comments.text: Nice, not only does white tile look and feel clean, but its also a material that can be effectively cleaned so no visible dirtiness remains (as opposed to other more absorbent materials that discolor quicker over time). This provides feedback that motivates people to clean and maintain. What other materials could provide similar benefits, perhaps at a lower cost?

Beauty  calms the mind and harmonizes the physical function. People are more motivated to keep something clean if it looks good to begin with, too.My mother always put a lot of attention into making the bathroom/w.c. area comfortable, inviting, easy to clean and beautiful. The white tile is quite nice.

focusing on your observation of the actual room strikes a chord with me. Mathew didn't have a fancy toilet that kept the room clean, he had a fancy room within which a bucket sat. It seems that it were the surroundings that actually kept the room clean. The tile, their color..WHITE resonates with me. Design things (rooms, toilets, walls) that are white and people will notice when things are unclean. One step further=>Could we design something that allows people to "see" bacteria/germs?

white_tiles_clean.title: White tiles = clean

robust_water_treatment.description:
I love this technology, it's actually purpose build for long-term water treatment in third-world countries, requires minimal maintenance, no chemical or fuel, and the component with the shortest lifespan will last ten years!


http://www.innovativeh2o.com/indexPageSlideshow/index.htm
robust_water_treatment.creator: 1c4172a4330dc070358ec205c46d4d1a
robust_water_treatment.title: Robust water treatment

vacuum_tanker.description:
In and around Kumasi, the Kumasi Metropolitan Authority (KMA) has outsourced the emptying of household and public toilets to private-sector operators like Owner’s Sanitation. Owners of personal latrines or public toilet blocks make a call to a private operator and within a few hours a driver and his assistant will arrive. 

With the vacuum truck, they suck out the contents of the pit (adding water if necessary) and drive it to the local landfill where they drain it into this pond. The liquid settles to to bottom and the shit hardens on top. Surprisingly, it did not smell much when we visited – more like a dairy farm than a dirty latrine.
vacuum_tanker.creator: dde2fb7aaee01b358a14703a9551c154

comments.text: What is the landfill like? Does it have any issues with the local water table? How much space is available versus already filled? How much stuff is already there that you could use to produce power or soil building materials? Think about everything you see there as an underutilized resource.If using human manure as fertilizer has too much stigma for individuals and households, then create  farms that uses the compost to grow a non-food cash crop like cattails. The roots can be harvested and used to produce large amounts of fuel alcohol. So, you put the manure through a biodigestion process to make methane biogas which you use to generate electricity, then you take the leftover nutrients and use them to grow an ethanol feedstock, which you distill. The alcohol powers vehicles and home cooking. The fermented leftovers from ethanol production are returned to the soil directly, or used as livestock feed, depending on the crop you choose. Methane biogas yields are Much higher when you have the manure of ruminants to add to the mix.At this point you begin to have a surplus of compost, so you expand the farms to include other nonfood crops like wood and other fibers for building and textiles. Prosperity and health come from cleaning up the garbage.A good use for some of the surplus nutrients, once they have been through a biodigester and/or a distiller, would be parks and schools with fruit and nut trees and other perennial food plants. Once the food is there on the trees and in gardens, people will eat it as part of their enjoyment of the park (especially children) and the stigma of the idea that some of the nutrients come from their own waste will be much reduced in subsequent generations.
There was an inspiration in here somewhere about an MIT group developing a bike-operated vacuum pump, which seems like it falls right between the vacuum truck and shoveling by hand.

Thanks for the comments! We have looked into humanure a bit and have found that there's not much of a local market for manure in Kumasi (people use manure from poultry which is free or nearly free). There's also a huge stigma against using human waste as fertilizer. 
That said, we're still really into the idea and hope that we could tie this into the system we design at some point. Perhaps selling it to larger commercial farms outside the city.

This is a really interesting post and also raises valid concerns, comments and questions.  Perhaps this handbook might help to address some of these questions: http://www.scribd.com/doc/270721/Humanure-Handbook, 'The Humanure Handbook, A Guide to Composting Human Manure'

Hi IDEO Field Team,Thanks for this very real, visual example of what's currently happening in Kumasi. I'm certainly not an expert on this, but seeing this truck transporting the waste made me wonder if there's a way to treat the waste and then use it for fertilizing crops? (I believe the idea is called "Humanure" http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humanure). Perhaps it wouldn't work if the country doesn't have the infrastructure to treat the waste before integrating it with the soil. But I liked the idea of using waste for a productive purpose (in this case, improved crop production through nutrient rich compost). I'll look forward to hearing more updates from your trip!

Is this pond, and others like it, near a densely populated area? What about watershed and water table contamination? If so, wouldn't any proposal involving their continued use run the risk of contributing to as many health hazards as it mitigates?  Just a thought. I like the re-purposing of the trucks though!

vacuum_tanker.title: Vacuum Tanker

inspiring_communities_to_solve_their_own.description:
In Brazil, some communities are organizing themselves into associations to collect and recycle garbage. This entrepreneurship movement leads to a next level of citizenship, where people are motivated to start taking action to solve all sorts of social problems without waiting for the Government. This is 'citizenship maturity' lacks in poor communities by lack of perspective, culture and education. Once they realize that they can work together, with a little push from NGO's and Government, great things can happen.
While the "catadores" collect garbage for recycling, they are also cleaning their local environment and generating extra income for their families.
Most importantly: this is an extremally simple and already tested concept that can be easily implemented.
inspiring_communities_to_solve_their_own.creator: 0d9fc1dd872df33240adabf004d4e62c

comments.text: The Zabbaleen in Egypt are another great example of this. They created an informal network that controls waste management in Cairo and recycles 80% of what they collect. The government's attempt at privatizing waste management have been unsuccessful in part because the Zabbaleen are so effective and well established. There are definitely human development issues in their community, but like the catadores they demonstrate the power of a community based model.

inspiring_communities_to_solve_their_own.title: Inspiring Communities to Solve their own Problems

latrine_design_and_construction_course_d.description:
Lifewater international offers courses on the design and construction of latrines.  Field Trainers learn about the connections between sanitation and disease, the biblical mandate for sanitation; how soil and groundwater influence proper latrine location, the construction, operation, and maintenance of various latrine designs, and how to adapt designs to accommodate people with special needs. 
Making the instruments and knowledge available to the low-income community in need could support local development and practices.

http://www.lifewater.org/sanitation-training
latrine_design_and_construction_course_d.creator: c186d344b513f4950e063174b5b150f4
latrine_design_and_construction_course_d.title: Latrine Design and Construction Course Description

mit_turning_waste_into_profit.description: "a company that seeks to improve sanitation conditions while simultaneously creating jobs and profit. Their model proposes to create a sustainable sanitation cycle that has significant positive environmental, health, economic and social impacts."
mit_turning_waste_into_profit.creator: cec980c4ed8474ecfd8e43adbfdb3617

comments.text: A couple of the other system concepts have trouble closing the money loop in terms of creating a financially self- sustaining system based solely on selling the energy & fertilizer outputs.  It would be great to see if Sanergy has found a way to get closer to doing that.

Glad Ideo is meeting up with Sanergy to find out more. Sounds like low-cost local sanitation centers supported by centralization of the actual waste to energy/fertilizer conversion and selling has a lot of potential.
This is a great model and really thoughtful systems solution. We've scheduled an expert interview with Sanergy to learn more.

mit_turning_waste_into_profit.title: MIT: Turning waste into profit

2_nutrients_are_1_composting_toilets..description:
Composting (or dry) toilets don't use any water and compost the waste so that you can put it straight on gardens and fields. Composting occurs at a steady pace and is best left for at least a year to decompose thoroughly. To avoid handling raw sewage, you can build a dual-chamber compost toilet. Each chamber is sized to fill up over a year. The seat can be switched between chambers, so that the second is filled whilst the first composts down completely!

Keeping urine separate is usually the key to a successful composting toilet, otherwise they can become anaerobic and smelly. As urine is high in nitrogen, potassium and phosphorus, if collected separately it can be used as a fertiliser (on non-food plants) when mixed about 1:10 in water.
2_nutrients_are_1_composting_toilets..creator: 70bb67c31f32594966075a9f74b0858a

comments.text: This is a great suggestion and we'd love other ideas for low-cost composting and urine diversion toilets. Please share more concepts related to affordable in-home toilet options!

2_nutrients_are_1_composting_toilets..title: #2 nutrients are #1 - Composting Toilets.

sparkling_gutters.description:
Solutions are more likely to take hold if they build on and leverage what matters to Ghanaian people - the sources of pride, shame, motivation, etc. that are meaningful in that particular cultural realm.  When gutters are considered part of a family or business' assets people will be motivated not only to keep them clean, but to keep others from dirtying them – creating a cycle of forces resulting in change.

Sparkling Gutters takes the home as a symbol of community membership and a reflection of one's status and leverages those forces by extending the concept of home ownership to include the gutters that currently are clogged with garbage and human waste.
sparkling_gutters.creator: d2db76877d32cd4c75d5747e8db3acc4

comments.text: This concept could be extended to include existing canals and ditches behind and between areas of high population density. These areas will need extensive remediation to stop the disease cycle even when the flying toilets are completely under control. Mass planting of native marsh plants can be a great source of civic pride as well as waterway purification.
All good Dan  we've added that into your opening description. You can always adjust your post using the Update button on the right. Great idea by the way!

Forgot to say in my concept description: When gutters are considered part of a family or business' assets, people will be motivated not only to keep them clean, but to keep others from dirtying them, creating a cycle of forces resulting in change.

sparkling_gutters.title: Sparkling Gutters

comments.text: Yes, that might help. I find camping places and villas a great source of inspiration given that they are faced with a similar problem; and often people who come to this places would like similar comfort as at home.  This is another interesting video that uses a bucket like in the previous post.  They added a ventilation tube and a little fan to deal the the odor problem.  Probably even solar energy panel could be used to power a fan extractor.  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6Vq6QeFFczY&feature=related
Seems like a really simple, inexpensive design. Could there be a way to close off the top to contain the smell?

class_for_trash_trash_in_bin_money_for_s.creator: 421540ac05e795a118fdbd9cd4f88592

comments.text: That sounds interesting .. I guess we can apply the same concept that is ask universities to donate credit ... or the likes. The reason I like the credit from universities is it is long term and education will payback for itself anyway. if you want we can arrange chat session with others to see if we come up with something. I am familiar with the six thinking hats and can volunteer to moderate the session.

The idea of increasing donations for sanitation is an interesting one. Are there ways in which people could make contributions that would provide subsidies for others to install toilets in their homes?

water_integration_with_holistic_mobile_s.description: Water and sewage infrastructure have been essential to most european cities success, wealth and prosperity. I wish we could do a big knowledge transfer and technology jump. With very little infrastructure required we could help apply and implement similar results in cities and areas where it is extremely difficult to start to build sewers and water pipes under housing areas below ground or in slumlike areas like for instance Dharavi, Mumbai or in cities close to oceans or big rivers. (or in areas that are stricken often with earthquakes)
water_integration_with_holistic_mobile_s.creator: 656863f55543ea22d1dbce290f237277

comments.text: I tried to add lots more related concepts and inspirations to show you more angles that i have thought about (but it failed to work on this borrowed computer).However I can mention that waste products from collecting poo and food waste will produce gas (for cooking) soil and fertilizer (for farms) and heat (for other processes or to generate electricity)These treatment plants could also be made into "scrubbing" pollutants and carbondioxide from the surrounding air.If process plant is placed floating in a river it could clean the water emitted from farms and factories.If placed on a coastal area : huge sails could be built to harvest morning mist and fog for fresh water.Roofs on the actual containers could harvest rain water.

Another combination is possible to make ice and transport it into cities. Or just make the water very cold increases its value. Along with these cooled containers is option to transport vegetables from rural farms into market places, which can maintain the quality up to ten times longer and therefor raising the market value of these produce. And creating additional income and value to the whole water treatment system.Cheap and effective container-technology exists : Zeer-pot-refrigeration, which is basically handmade ceramic pots that works without electricity.
Extra electricity that is not used in the processes could also be sold (as batteries or other means)Those income could build more renewable energy generators and treatment plants.

water_integration_with_holistic_mobile_s.title: Water Integration with holistic mobile systems

the_better_place_model.creator: 53abcbb57525d756a2e5f2d47438440c

comments.text: Hi, I wonder whether you could make a mini dry-composting toilet out of a bucket. This may make it safer for transportation and less odorous - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Composting_toilet and as someone else pointed out on another post maybe a dabbawalla type system can come in handy.

It's an interesting concept, but I imagine that the transport of thousands of buckets "filled" might be very complicated, if we consider other logistic options. I think it would be more productive if the user empties his own bucket, in a collection point. Some adaptations in the design of the bucket allow this process to be safe for the user. But despite this, I think this system better than methods that use plastic bags. Not even the biodegradable bags are 100% environmentally friendly. Much energy is expended to produce them.

This is a model we've been thinking alot about. Are there ways to trade out in-home toilets or bases filled with waste for cleaning while ensuring a family always has access to the toilet within the home?

the_better_place_model.title: The Better Place Model

very high potential

Its got too many open questions right now to say either way

navigation_system_for_flying_toilets_.description:
Why let the dirty toilets "fly" about randomly? Why let them create disease? Why let waste be littered around? Why not have a navigation system that directs these to a place where they can be used effectively as resources?

This concept draws inspiration from the "Kabadi Walahs" of Delhi, India and their "reverse supply chain" for waste management. The barter of human waste collection service (basically poop-collection) with recyclable material from households can make it economically viable for the service provider and sustainable for the community.
navigation_system_for_flying_toilets_.creator: d07fc5d0348bcdf0a3ca0f36bd91d622

comments.text: Making the system more efficient and effect is interesting.  Maybe if the service is not on a daily basis but on an 'as needed' basis (bigger families might need pick-up sooner) someone in the household texts a number on their mobile phone to the sanitation system which alerts the drivers that that specific house needs a pickup.  The navigation system could string together as-needed pickups in real time allowing the drivers to continue to travel on efficient routes.  There is some very interesting potential there.The biggest hurdle, though, might be establishing the biogas / fertilizer plants needed to make the economics of this concept work.  Some incentive might need to be offered to attract large companies to invest in something like that.  But this is not to say that it can't be done!  It just has to be figured out.Thanks for the concept Saahil!

if this system starts to earn profits higher than the costs, the company should start to pay a small fee to each house. Or a reward, a useful item, perhaps a practical product that helps with domestic cleaning. More of a symbolic gesture, this fee would be even more important as an incentive to try harder to give all waste to this company.

This concept suggests a possible theme for uniforms and compensation for sanitation workers. What if sanitation workers were compensated equally with and uniformed similarly to bus drivers, train conductors or airplane flight staff? This would help people know how to value the social standing and contribution of sanitation workers.

Great inputs people.
Alessandro, I too was thinking of a way to reduce AWC frequency to make it more viable. If there is a way to store the human waste for longer without the associated decay and odour, that will be great !!!
Maybe there can be one depot per locality where all households can submit their chamber pots & recyclable waste. This would limit the decay and odour to only one part of the locality, where it can be controlled/partially treated. Also, this would make the collection easier and it would need to be done once in 2 or 3 days as suggested by you.
Vincent's concept of using Toilets Lids would definitely reduce spillage and make handling easy. PeePoo bags as included in his concept also seem to be more suitable for collection and transport (unless they burst) as compared to traditional chamber pots.

It's a good idea. I'm proposing a sort of "smelly toilet", which allows families to store their waste for more days. That would reduce spending on the daily transport of boxes and also spent on cleaning them. Take a look at the process Unibox. Many families live in houses of one room, which would force them to live with the odor and germs in the same place where they feed, for example.In his illustration, I saw a truck of garbage collection. It would be interesting if he could collect the garbage and manure.In my country, Brazil, a truck goes down the street from 2 to 3 times a week. I do not know what is the frequency in Kumasi. Probably less. So it would be interesting if the waste could be stored longer, without disturbing the family.
Nice modeling on the kabaari system Saahil. I was just marvelling how well this works here in Mumbai the other day  while back home in New Zealand things aren't nearly as user-centric nor efficient.

Nice title Saahil. Really drew my curiosity to read more. Your system would also work nicely with Jocelyn's "sanitization seal" (http://bit.ly/fMPmSl ) and Larry's "gold medal service" (http://bit.ly/hzEr7Z ), which could be given to collectors by the government/government-authorized treatment facility for each chamber pot they properly dispose of/treat/clean.

hand_sanitizer_.description: There is an increasing number of hand sanitizer wall dispensers appearing at various locations in London. Last month I saw one in a tube station and in a cinema. Locations where nothing like this has been provided before. Free Hygiene in urban areas is extremely interesting and could be initiated together with a government body to help keep germs at bay.
