hand_sanitizer_.title: Hand Sanitizer

decals_for_bathroom_doors_and_walls.description:
Print decals with temperature and/or pressure sensitive ink. Place them on doors and stalls in bathrooms throughout a city. If a person pushes the door open on this decal will leave their handshape on it and it diminishes slowly over an hour.
The campaign should be accompanied with slogans that is in local language/dialect for promotion of washing hands with water and soap.
Local cleaning company or large soap-label or similar could be sponsor for the project.
decals_for_bathroom_doors_and_walls.creator: 656863f55543ea22d1dbce290f237277

comments.text:
This also gives you a hint as to who has used the bathroom recently.
A mother with children could choose a stall that has other childrens' handprints on it, if it might indicate that it was clean enough for another child to use before.

decals_for_bathroom_doors_and_walls.title: Decals for bathroom doors and walls

lifebuoy.description:
I'll leave it to the Unilever folks to get the story 100% accurate, but Unilever has a soap brand called Lifebuoy that was originally marketed in the UK and US but quickly spread globally and now seems to only exist outside of the US and Western Europe (SE Asia, India, Africa...)

It's interesting for this project because in its effort to promote health and expand the soap using market, Lifebuoy is heavily involved in hygiene education programs.
lifebuoy.creator: d814e015f931aba24d24c2f12025dc3c
lifebuoy.title: Lifebuoy

sanitation_a_threat_or_an_opportunity.description: Urine, if separated from the solid excrements, can actually be a very efficient fertilizer.
sanitation_a_threat_or_an_opportunity.creator: d58cec0b1bf65176a49ea2cd4336cc06

comments.text: It seems to me that urine is a good fertalizer and not dangerous. Is this true? Dog owners don't clear up dog piss. in addition, it is quickly abosrbed into the soil. Excrement seems to be the problem!
Very interesting on the nitrogen value in urine!  For an urban setting, how do we keep the value of seperating the urine out, if there are no nearby needs for it?

The interesting thing is that fertilizer that people can assemble locally (separated urine and feaces and food waste in separate containers) is replacing the need to purchase expensive fertilizers that needs to be transported into the rural areas from industrial areas far away.
Even small domestic plots of land where you grow for your own household is improved with very simple methods. Just dig a hole in the middle of your field, pour the food waste or feaces into it. cover with top soil. and sprinkle the urine over the field. Plant whatever, and your yield improves. But do not plough, it reduces the nitrogen, carbon and humidity retention capabilities from the soil.

sanitation_a_threat_or_an_opportunity.title: Sanitation: a threat or an opportunity?

people_powered_poo_pump.description: Cambridge University researcher Nate Sharpe designed this prototype bicycle-powered vacuum pump/tank system which works by putting the end of a hose into a pit latrine - common in slums in Africa, Asia and other parts of the developing world - and cycling in place for a few minutes on a bike stand.  This allows the sludge to be sucked into a bucket attached to the back of the bike.
people_powered_poo_pump.creator: 4f8b3ea88d13faf1a2fe3d5dc729c8e3

comments.text: This ties in nicely to Jocelyn Wyatt's Zoomlion inspiration, as well as the whole idea of mobile (bike-based) enterprises that Meena Kadri brought up (http://bit.ly/cd6PeZ).
Awesome use for human power transport of poo, hopefully to a local biogas facility for cleaning up the waste by using it to generate clean fuel.

Great!It actually reminds me of the project of building playground swings and carousels that are pumping up water from deep wells from the action of the kids playing around. (playpumps.com , spanpumpsindia.com and so on.... )
These combined could also be turned into a human-powered air-tight compost-facility for combined food waste. There is big risks of leaking dangerous gases out of large-scale compost-systems, and building air-confined composts need someone turning around in it, and an exact controlled temperature. This could be powered with bicycles in places without grid. And if the compost is air-tight you could collect gases and use it as a fuel to cook with or to generate electricity.

people_powered_poo_pump.title: People powered poo pump

advanced_technology_for_water.description:
With the advanced hydration of the technology called, "Plasma Activated Water (PAW)," for the first time in the world, we have hydration of the cells as nature intended, and when the cells receive better hydration, they are put into a state which allows the cells to do what they do best, i.e., create what is called homeostasis (balance) and when in such a state, the cells know how to take care of what is needed to eliminate in the cellular environment any support for unhealthy conditions.  http://kindrop.abc4all.net

With this ability to Improve Health Maintenance (IHM) http://abc4all.net/8petals.htm, it is clear that the world can look forward to Better Water for a Better World http://abc4all.net/bwbw.htm.
advanced_technology_for_water.creator: 75fcd9b0a7d03c99c6a7e7e7cff1c073
advanced_technology_for_water.title: Advanced Technology for Water

_we_bring_cleanliness_and_health_.description: Reframe the role of the waste collector.  It's what they bring, not what they take away.
_we_bring_cleanliness_and_health_.creator: 489a9ab30b5c5567dac8a89b769df599

comments.text: I love the optimistic approach on this idea

A few years back, one of the English princes (I think it was William) went on a charity cleanup campaign to physically help clean up a slum area. All the students on the trip were lodged together and shared chores. The article I read said that included cleaning the toilet.I see that as a brilliant move by Elizabeth, who has always valued hard work. From now on, all any English woman should have to say to convince her son to clean the toilet is something like, "If the prince can do it, so can you."What if people in Kumasi (and everywhere) could see pictures of affluent people cheerfully cleaning toilets and living in a clean vibrant environment? An advertising campaign of famous people photographed cleaning toilets, with the slogan "If I can do it, so can you." could go a really long way.

Wow, Avi - thanks so much for sharing Lakshmi's story. You can practically hear in her voice how degraded and ashamed she feels. And yet, if you turn it around like Larry is suggesting, what Lakshmi is really doing is finding a way to support her family, no matter how awful or tough the work. 
Is there a way to shift everyone's mindset so that people like Lakshmi are congratulated and celebrated for their work as entrepreneurs? Jocelyn, you asked about how we can make this a more dignified occupation - in my opinion the best way to do that is to show that this work can help lift families out of poverty. Perhaps there's a business model in here somewhere, ie: local entrepreneurship around waste management. The way I see it, the ownership and autonomy that come through entrepreneurship are powerful motivators, and there's nothing like making money to help you feel empowered and proud of yourself!

We've been thinking alot about things like uniforms, business cards, fancy titles (sanitation engineer), etc. 
Are there other ways to make waste collection a more dignified occupation?

We need a way for people like Lakshmi Devi to make a more dignified living:http://news.bbc.co.uk/today/hi/today/newsid_9172000/9172301.stmHow can we provide them with tools to do this work with honor?

_we_bring_cleanliness_and_health_.title: "We bring cleanliness and health"

toilet_card_pay_per_month_not_pay_per_us.description: In order to encourage higher usage of public toilets, the deterrents must be eliminated.  Two main deterrents are the payment to be made on every use and the comparative discomfort involved in walking to the public toilet. Pay-per-month, instead of Pay-per-use would eliminate these and achieve desired behavioural change. Enter "Toilet Card".
toilet_card_pay_per_month_not_pay_per_us.creator: d07fc5d0348bcdf0a3ca0f36bd91d622

comments.text: Continuing pay-per-use option will also give the Toilet Card some aspirational value for those who can't afford. Once the aspirations of owning a Toilet Card build up (over, say, a period of 5-6 months), then once-a-month payment scheme can be converted to once-a-week as you suggested. That would increase affordability, and bring a lot more people under the net due the aspirational value built up earlier.I think this must be included into the model.

Very interesting Saahil. I think this membership card could definitely work with a certain segment of the population and may be even more attractive if it provided access to a network of toilets, rather than just one location. These cards are likely to be shared between family members/friends, so great that you built this into your model with family toilet cards. However, for the poorest segment, the savings needed to purchase such a card may still be out of reach. Thus, its important to also maintain pay-per-use options, and even expand to include lower-cost, shorter time-period unlimited use options (say pay-per-week) to lower the price point.

toilet_card_pay_per_month_not_pay_per_us.title: TOILET CARD

public_bathrooms_funded_by_advertising.description: Turn the traditional business model of pay-per-use toilets upside down!  Build public bathrooms that are free to use, funded by targeted advertising presented to the users.
public_bathrooms_funded_by_advertising.creator: 7c8e822d3f154bb2b046f6e1085eea54

comments.text:
I think this concept has a potential for a sustainable and neat solution. 
If the toilets are designed to be maintained by the funding of advertising companies, I think there should be a way that the competitiveness(the cleanness of the public bathroom) may matter.
If not, there is a possibility that the bathroom may be advertising while is not maintained in a clean sate.
The Nigerian Wagon Toilets use a mixed model including advertising http://bit.ly/hlHq4P along the lines of what Alessandro raises.

I imagine the cost of maintaining a public bathroom is too high to be funded only through advertising. But partnerships would be signed between large companies, local companies, NGOs and government, so that each is accountable for part of the cost of maintenance. A company like Unilever could provide products for higiente and at the same time, explore the inner and outer space for advertising. The government has a duty to do their part too! There is no bathroom pblico100% free, since the population pays taxes to maintain the sanitation of the city, even though there is no sanitation!

public_bathrooms_funded_by_advertising.title: Public Bathrooms Funded By Advertising!

_no_littering.description: To me, clean means healthy and respectful of the environment.  It is both a state of being and a behavior.  I think an effective model is reinforcing it by the law.
_no_littering.creator: 8757541db3a21588d7952dbb8fb5fe29

comments.text: Nice link Meena to see anti-litter poets.  Also I was thinking clean is both a conscious effort and an act.

I like your point that it's a state of being *and* a behaviour, Kirsten. And I guess a complimentary path to encourage people to be "healthy and respectful of the environment" is through awareness building. Here's a great anti-litter campaign by the City of Philadelphia: http://bit.ly/bM0ngz

_no_littering.title: No Littering!

glo_germ_for_hygiene.description: An earlier posting showed a similar image but without too much explanation... there are a number of products (liquids, powders, etc) that when placed on hands and then washed off show the before/after effectiveness of handwashing at removing 'germs'.  The blacklight shows the otherwise invisible 'germ' solution...
glo_germ_for_hygiene.creator: d814e015f931aba24d24c2f12025dc3c

comments.text: I've heard this demonstration campaign is quite successful in India with the Lifeboy soap promotions that the Unilever Shakti Ammas run.

glo_germ_for_hygiene.title: Glo Germ for hygiene

portable_privacy_screen.description: People still go out into open spaces to poop. Taking along a portable privacy screen might establish a modicum of dignity.
portable_privacy_screen.creator: cb0e09c205b2413162b95a8b79401432

comments.text: I wonder what the range of preferences is on this in Kumasi? Questions like: Does it bother you to be seen defecating? Is it important to be able to see all around you when you are defecating?

portable_privacy_screen.title: Portable Privacy Screen

i_know_it_s_clean_because_it_smells_like.description: the scent of grapefruits. I love that sharp acidic scent! It makes me feel as though things are clean. And actually, some acidic fruits and natural sources have cleaning effects - coconut oil for example. How do we leverage natural resources to help build smart waste management and sanitation solutions?
i_know_it_s_clean_because_it_smells_like.creator: da9b15fdda5025b00f048e1cde77706d

comments.text: Great idea!

Indeed  and I think this relates to the post from the IDEO team on white tiles: http://bit.ly/e0B5qK in terms of users' associations. I also notice here in India that when things like meat are being sold that a masking-scent may be employed by the vendor  often through burning frankincense.

i_know_it_s_clean_because_it_smells_like.title: I know it's clean because it smells like....

a_workable_public_toilet_with_incentives.description: Why solve one challenge when you can solve several at once?  This concept is for a public toilet system that: manages the waste disposal process; promotes personal hygiene; reduces the bacterial hazard at source; minimises water consumption; reduces maintenance costs; and harnesses the different motivations of men, women and children to encourage them to use, and maintain, the facilities.
a_workable_public_toilet_with_incentives.creator: 46667ca2c465a60bdc1c8b66b17b6cd2

comments.text: I read it, ok? : ) Some concepts are a little trickier, but I think I understand. If composting or dehydration of the stool are made on the spot, really interesting is the separation of feces and urine. I understand that in your project, the urine is separated from feces by a gravity system. This can be a problem if the objective is to make urine as fertilizer, because if the urine initially traverse the same path of feces, it will certainly be contaminated. The system of sanitary bowl separator with urine and feces is a success in several countries... why not adopt it, if the objective really is the separation? It's a small problem for men, but they urinate in a urinal. In this system, urine has a low rate of contamination, and can easily be used as fertilizer. Iffinal objective, however,is adigester would not be a problem mixing it all! In reality it is much easier to transport vacuum system.If the objective is to reduce costs, imagine it's cheaper to build bathrooms that are only temporary reservoirs that composters complete. I think that composting centralized in one location would be less expensive. This also reduces the size of the bathrooms. Squat toilet type less transmit diseases, the butt becomes more clean (do not laugh, it's true!), cleaning is easier and less expensive and there is a tradition in African countries. Here are some models in this link: http://www.flickr.com/photos/gtzecosan/with/3282070261/I think the device on which you spoke, mainly to cover that opens and closes, could easily be adapted to this model. I liked the UV light. Good idea! How about combining it with an ozonator? The collection of rainwater for cleaning is a great idea. Nobody talked about it yet here... Phew! Unable to read my terrible English until the end?
Some great thoughts here Adrian  we're glad you discovered us! You can still add images + diagrams using the Update button on the right of this post.
Your "logic of public toilets" makes a lot of sense. Wish you could explain some of the mechanics with graphics/diagrams.

Yes, there are definitely some nice thoughts in here. I particularly appreciate your pointing out some of the advantages of public vs private toilets and the use of simple mechanical devices to improve hygiene.
There are some really good thoughts in this concept. Nice work!

a_workable_public_toilet_with_incentives.title: A workable public toilet with incentives and side-effects (quite long, sorry!)

certificate_of_cleanliness_calendar.description: This builds on Larry’s concept of “Gold Medal Service”. Imagine if public toilet users could transparently tell whether a facility consistently met high standards for hygiene and disposal. This could become a reality by leveraging government sanctioned disposal services (such as vacuum trucks). Each facility that uses such a service would receive an annual “Certificate of Cleanliness Calendar” posted at the entrance. Each week/month (or however often the service is meant to be used), when the service is used (which could consist of not just disposal, but also hygiene inspections or even cleaning bundled right in), a dated star sticker/seal/stamp is affixed to the appropriate location on the calendar. In addition, part of the certificate could include words and illustrations that explain the importance of hygiene and steps for cleaning toilets and yourself after toilet use.
certificate_of_cleanliness_calendar.creator: b15ab3f829f0f897fe507ef548741afb

comments.text: Absolutely Jocelyn, for families and service providers, a full calendar certificate could also become a point of pride/status. Thanks for the build! Definitely something I hadn't thought of.

This could also be used for the families who have installed a toilet in their homes and for the service providers who are disposing of the waste appropriately. I love the idea of awards for compliant behavior.

certificate_of_cleanliness_calendar.title: Certificate of Cleanliness Calendar

making_and_profiting_from_night_soil_and.creator: 680e89809965ec41e64dc7e447f175ab

comments.text: I like the educational aspect of this program. People need help learning how to take better care of themselves and the environment.

making_and_profiting_from_night_soil_and.title: Making (and Profiting) from Night Soil and the Songs of Sanitation

cleanwaste.description: From their website: Cleanwaste is the world's leader in personal human waste management "when plumbing's not available".
cleanwaste.creator: 489a9ab30b5c5567dac8a89b769df599

comments.text: I like this idea, seems like a much better design than some of the camper toilets. I think design is one problem and removal of waste is another that can be solved via forming of a franchise business.

This product is good and it can surely improve the waste management. However, this is more short term solution since we need people to take and empty the toilet case. This solution also requires procurement of disposable resources.

cleanwaste.title: Cleanwaste

scrubbing_incrazy_clean.description: How can adequate hand cleaning inform how we deal with waste in developing countries? How can we change behavior + provide mechanisms for effectively cleaning hands?

scrubbing_incrazy_clean.title: Scrubbing in==crazy clean

somehow_linking_cell_phones_into_the_pic.description: Knowing that there's more cell phones than toilets in Africa, and that they're an aspirational purchase for families of low income, how can we link this sexiness into toilets?
somehow_linking_cell_phones_into_the_pic.creator: ad3ad14deeacd26502d0036312c4efa8

comments.text: Could there be a way to use cell phones to document the status of public toilets in Ghana? Perhaps photos could be taken of public toilets in disrepair to let donors, the government, or the private operators to know they need to be fixed/cleaned.

What about an SMS "petition" to get people engaged with the issue? For example, a person can "vote" or "be counted" by texting in a code and the phone company (or whoever) can donate services or money to an area.
Or use the cameras on the phone - crowdsource what a lack of sanitation looks like, and bring the campaign to wealthier nations' bar bathrooms - "You're going now, but imagine if you had to go HERE" with a pic of what bathrooms in some of these countries look like, and then a prompt to text in a short code for a donation to a group that can improve facilities.
Nice discussion guys. We're looking forward to Concepts which build on this Inspiration!
This is a great idea, Andy. A wonderful way to leverage existing behaviors and assets to create widespread change!

Have you guys heard of the Charmin toilet paper (P&G brand) iPhone app called Sit or Squat? It helps users find the cleanest bathrooms worldwide and it's created quite a buzz: http://www.mobilemarketer.com/cms/news/advertising/3017.htmlI think the idea of leveraging the "cool" factor of cell phones in a sanitation campaign is really clever. I wonder how we could create an engaging and culturally-relevant cell phone/bathroom campaign that might also help educate people on waste disposal, where to find clean toilets etc? Great idea!
Hi Andy,When you have more cell phones than toilets, there's bound to be opportunities based on this disparity. Thanks for the links to some interesting examples. Definitely got my wheels turning.

Someone on another site I participate on suggested the idea of bicycle powered cell phone charging. If toilet cleaners are kept informed of what needs doing by cell phone, and use bicycles to get around, it would be great if they could charge their phones at the same time.

somehow_linking_cell_phones_into_the_pic.title: Somehow linking cell phones into the picture - making sanitation sexy!

seeeeeeeeeeee_the_germs_in_action_you_wi.description:
Using cheap and powerful magnifying glass. 
Let us innovate to produce cheep, resistant, tools in forms of toys to make us see the germs in action. Let us do it. If everybody were able to see the germs they are more likely be careful and they will clean and perhaps cooperate to keep the place clean and sort the trash etc.
seeeeeeeeeeee_the_germs_in_action_you_wi.creator: 421540ac05e795a118fdbd9cd4f88592
seeeeeeeeeeee_the_germs_in_action_you_wi.title: Seeeeeeeeeeee the Germs!!!! IN ACTION, you will clean guaranteed.

deploy_moldering_privies_to_make_gold_ou.description: Moldering Privies are the most cost effective and eco-friendly solution to human waste disposal
deploy_moldering_privies_to_make_gold_ou.creator: cb0e09c205b2413162b95a8b79401432

comments.text: Drawing a parallel to industrial composting, as well as agriculture, winemaking, cheesemaking, and other time-intensive product manufacture, there needs to be land set aside for the bugs to do their work over time, which means infrastructure and people to watch over the work in process.
I really like the simplicity of the molding privies; it's so simple yet so effective and efficient. Thanks, for sharing!

Thanks Nathan & Vincent. The compost box could be modular, allowing it to be easily replaced (slid in under the privy?) and portable (pulled by a tricycle?) allowing it to be taken away for storage at a central site for the composting to complete. All this work could be done as a profitable business service.

Thanks for the interesting post Avi. I think I used one of these recently while camping. For these solutions, also important to have a system in place for maintaining (i.e. emptying) over time: though it sounds like the moldering privy is easier to maintain assuming usage volume isn't too high.
Wow, that's pretty cool Avi! thanks for this, really inspiring how you can construct something so simple from such simple materials and (in some areas) readily available areas.

deploy_moldering_privies_to_make_gold_ou.title: Deploy Moldering Privies to Make Gold out of Human Waste

pet_bottle_bricks.description: PET bottles filled with dirt/sand can be used instead of bricks for building. I have served communities where we helped underprivileged families build latrines with PET bottles. The latter was a substitute for open-air latrines which pose disease risks.

comments.text: Out standing!, Will start working in my part of the WorldMamnoonPakistan

comments.text: and i guess the question is where to dump the dumps?
I agree with Kristine. If we can re use the existing cartons. Everything comes in cartons these days. We can make use of them.

celebrate_toilet_ownership.description: Building a toilet and taking responsibility for proper waste management is a big deal.  It's good for a family and it's better for the community.  Find some way to celebrate it.
celebrate_toilet_ownership.creator: d814e015f931aba24d24c2f12025dc3c

comments.text: Great concept, Jeff! In Ghana, anything is grounds for a good party! I bet they would love the idea! I like the suggestion of Vincet: inspection to verify cleanliness of the installations. Such monitoring could be without notice ... the supervisor would come in the house by surprise ... the toilet considered the most well maintained (street, neighborhood, etc..) receive an award and a tribute in public. It's just an idea, ok? Congratulations!

Clever ideas for making toilet ownership a point of pride and cause for celebration. Will definitely need local involvement to adapt this to work effectively in Ghana. Also, for the badge of ownership that you suggest be placed on the outside of the home, I think the "Certificate of Cleanliness Calendar" (http://bit.ly/f89eSF) might work well to not only signal toilet ownership, but also quality toilet maintenance (as suggested by Jocelyn).

I love the idea of ceremonies too. 
I could imagine a celebration of a new toilet (public, private or hybrid)  including an educational theme as a puppet show and a game the children and any interested adults could play as the host gives sample sanitation supplies (peepoo bag or similar) to all the guests.

This is little bit similar to other concept : badges and stars for homes that have their own bathroom.The Ceremony idea is new, and very interesting.I think it could be made very efficient if it was combined with visible announcement on how this family improves their general health, avoiding diseases and reduces their number of days being absent from school or work."Healthier and prouder toilet owner"This will maybe come to mean that this family can work little more days to get little more yearly income, and through keeping their children in school more days will make them get better opportunities to get better jobs in the future. Hopefully neighbourhoods can make this link and connection.

celebrate_toilet_ownership.title: Celebrate Toilet Ownership

making_sanitation_desirable_and_valuable.description: I just had to include this image, taken in the bathroom of a broken down bookshop in London in the 1980's, run by a heroin addict.  For me, this image takes the conversation away from sanitation and into inspiration...what does it mean to make the toilet more than simply functional?  Are there ways to encourage people to use toilets rather than not?  What if there were communication opportunities that were possible?  Education? News?
making_sanitation_desirable_and_valuable.creator: eb6c217879bc78f7799e2633bb41d205
making_sanitation_desirable_and_valuable.title: Making sanitation desirable and valuable

self_cleaning_litter_boxes.description: Litter boxes are brilliant. And self-cleaning litter boxes? Even more brilliant. They're surely not the solution to this challenge, but they're inspirational in that they take a very different approach to capturing and sorting and removing waste from living areas. They're low maintenance. They turn liquid waste to solid waste to make it filterable. They deodorize. And they sanitize. Brilliant.
self_cleaning_litter_boxes.creator: 223793f812cfbcbda82cb755f1a7f149

comments.text: great analogous behavior to be inspired by!  As a cat owner I know how hard it is to get cats to understand the rationale for not defecating on the floor....

self_cleaning_litter_boxes.title: Self-Cleaning Litter Boxes

get_people_to_aim.description:
A great innovation I noticed in the Amsterdam Schipol airport toilets. According to statistics, since the icon of the fly has been in use, it improves the aim. If a man sees a fly, he aims at it. The general hygiene in the toilets has improved by 80%, apart from putting a smile on everyone's faces.
http://www.urinalfly.com/
get_people_to_aim.creator: 80fa1bf5dc7b7b6f55e54661b4ca5a0d

creating_a_network_of_educated_mothers.description: Changing behavior, especially among adults, is a very tough thing to do. Given that, I suggest we think about how we can teach the youngest generations in areas like Kumasi to be responsible about their sanitation and waste disposal habits - after all, it's today's kids who will be running these communities very soon. And I think women and mothers are the perfect demographic and vehicle to deliver these kinds of messages.
creating_a_network_of_educated_mothers.creator: 884b3f632f6af8e3f87b26795b8a4f31

comments.text: Nice idea Ashley.There is also in Ethiopia a Health Extension Program implementation is a sizeable cadre of new Health Extension Workers (HEWs), who are trained in a one-year programme to implement a Health Extension Package of 16 healthcare activities at the village level. By 2010, 30,000 health extension workers (HEWs), almost all young women from the communities they serve, will be trained and distributed in pairs to live and work at the village-level throughout the country.As a preventive health program, the HEP promotes four areas of care: Disease Prevention and Control, Family Health, Hygiene and Environmental Sanitation, and Health Education and Communication. HEWs spend 75 percent of their time visiting families in their homes and performing outreach activities in the community. They spend the remaining 25 percent of their time providing services at the health posts, including giving immunizations and injectable contraceptives, among other health and educational services. The Health Extension Workers also work in close collaboration with voluntary workers, such as community-based reproductive health agents (CBRHA) to provide reproductive health and family planning services at the household level.
Great exmaples Avi. And here's another one from Mumbai  the Mahila Milan micro-savings initiative: http://bit.ly/9BmSjM

Ashley, Lijjat Papad and the Barefoot College come to mind as potential women-led networks to learn from and collaborate with to transfer meta-skills to enhance the successful implementation of this wonderful concept:http://priyaishankar.blogspot.com/2010/05/first-off-happy-late-mothers-day-i-hope.html

Maria, it's so funny you mention Switch - that's one of my new fave books! And yes, my idea to borrow from the Pachamama Alliance's work with women and mothers is very in line with that story in the book.

This is great -- regardless of which *tangible* solution is chosen, there's no doubt that harnessing women (moms) to implement social change is powerful. 
This post reminds me of the story in the book "Switch" (by Chip and Dan Heath) about how an aid worker in Vietnam used moms who were feeding their children more nutritious foods as (essentially) workshop leaders, teaching other mothers in the village how to improve the food they were preparing. The change was effective because it didn't come from an "outsider" like an NGO  -- it was local ("she is one of us, so she really gets it!") and also feasible ("if she can do this, so can I!"). 
No matter which design or combination of other designs are chosen,  grassroots groups of "moms-teaching-other-moms" should be used as a key "marketing" tactic!
Yes!  Mom is the most primary and important educator.

http://www.child-to-child.org/resources/index.html The Child-to Child Trust has extensive educational resources and training for teaching children to support each other in being safe and healthy. Many years ago, I saw an early version of their manual and it was amazing. The current one is available on the page linked above. "Participatory Approach to Promoting Health in Schools - a Child-to-Child training manual. Their materials are in use in over 70 countries. I'm sure this program could be adapted to teach mothers and other community members as well as teachers.

Great ideas, Ashley! We've heard alot about how children can be agents of change regarding sanitation - encouraging their parents to install toilets in their homes. 
We're really interested in other concepts related to how to spread awareness and communicate the importance of household sanitation.

wassup_diepsloot.description:
WASSUP (Water Amenities Sanitation Services Upgrading Program) is an initiative to improve the public ablution facilities in the township of Diepsloot, Johannesburg, by residents for residents. Initiated by Global Studio (see www.theglobalstudio.com) in 2007 , the project is now led by Diepsloot locals who have worked to repair the toilets, drains and taps in their township. The work has a direct impact on the daily lives of an estimated 70,000 residents who have not had access to adequate sanitation infrastructure. 
A website has been started - see www.wassupdiepsloot.com - which is currently under construction.
wassup_diepsloot.creator: fe96e1403409d1d80835741b2edc6e70

comments.text: Great to hear Natacha! We're keen to hear from you and other Global Studio participants in our upcoming Concepting phase  what proposals can be submitted based on learnings from Johannesburg? Are there aspects of the initiative which you feel could be replicated/scaled?
Being part of the Global Studio 2009, I am so thrilled to see how much the WASSUP progressed in a year. Now the community leads the project, kudos!
I'm loving the community-inclusive approach here!

wassup_diepsloot.title: WASSUP Diepsloot

ecological_toilets_compost_or_biogas_net.description: The knowledge and networks needed to quickly raise the quality of sanitation and jump-start eco-friendly businesses have reached critical mass. Let's leverage best practices from all over the globe to restore dignity to a core human need.
ecological_toilets_compost_or_biogas_net.creator: cb0e09c205b2413162b95a8b79401432

comments.text: Here's a link to a dutch organization supporting biogas and biofuels development that is "pro poor" in many places all over the world.http://www.snvworld.org/en/ourwork/Pages/Renewable%20Energy.aspx

The biodigester idea is a good one and has been around for a while; I have seen studies where it is used in rural India.   This actually addresses both the sanitation issue as well as the creation of more fertile crops.  Great suggestion Avi.
The biogas sanitation pdf above contains huge amount of relevant information for this challenge.
I love how you've enriched the presentation with additional videos and downloads. The one about conditions and solutions in Romania is especially informative and moving.

I find it interesting a solar dehydrator for the waste to a separate location from that where is the toilet. Thus, it is possible to construct a toilet rather than just two. The waste would be taken to the solar drying chambers, for example, monthly. The chambers could be closed for a longer time for dehydration and disinfection of waste. When a chamber was full, would be closed and another camera would be used. There is a process as smooth as composting, but is much simpler. I believe that the construction of chambers of dehydration vastly diminish the cost of the construction of toilets.
http://www.safisana.org/ is an organization working on a pilot program for a franchise model biogas plant in Ghana. openIDEO team reported in the ghanasan blog http://ghanasan.wordpress.com/
Nice compact presentation of this great concept Avi.

ecological_toilets_compost_or_biogas_net.title: Ecological Toilets + Compost or Biogas + Networked Entrepreneurs = Everybody Wins

biomass_recovery_increases_air_water_pol.description: What if there was a way to collect human and animal waste in such a way to decrease air pollution, decrease water pollution, while creating a sustainable source of energy?  I'm in!  And the technology is available for large scale agriculture.  The challenge is if it can be adapted to a much smaller scale.
biomass_recovery_increases_air_water_pol.creator: 621c98f7bc858672927e97eba28670b0

comments.text:
Currently, I have a friend in Guatemala that is working to design a stove that will effectively run on biogas converted from human and animal waste. They are in the prototyping phase. I agree with TJ that the the small scale application is necessary for real grassroots impact. 
http://www.aidg.org/biodigesters.htm

I saw something like this on the Pheonix project done by International University of Holodynamics.  http://www.holodynamics.com/RemediationPark/Remediation_Park.shtml
That is the link to it.  HE calls it a Remediation Park
Great provocations  would be good to explore further in the upcoming Concept Phase.

http://www.patervis.com/sintex.html has units sized for families of four or more.The system works better if you have at least some herbivore manure to add to the digester. All sizes of these are lightweight enough to be easily carried when empty.

I agree, there must be a way to learn from agricultural waste management practices.  one interesting system I saw on an organic dairy farm once was a moving milking shed.  one of the big problems with concentrated animal production facilities (industrial farming) is the large amount of waste product all produced at one site.  The point of the mobile dairy was to move the location of the waste every week or so, so that there wasn't a pile in one area, but it was evenly distributed over fields. That is, because they wanted to use the waste as fertilister.  Not that I think moving human toilets is a particularly good idea... but for the sake of the process --- throwing new ideas up, I will add it :)

biomass_recovery_increases_air_water_pol.title: Biomass recovery increases, Air / water polution deacreases
